records.dc:title: Imperial Hotel during construction, Quilpie, 1925
records.dc:creator: Metcalfe, Jack
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns construction sites building construction scaffolding Quilpie - Hotels - Imperial Hotel, 1925 Quilpie (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Construction of the Imperial Hotel, on the corner of Brolga and Buln Buln Streets, which was built by Harry Corones. The photograph was taken by Jack Metcalfe, a carpenter on the site. Harry Corones' involvement in the hotel industry extended to Quilpie, where he operated three hotels, managed by his nephews Jim and Harry Corones. In August 1921 the Quilpie Hotel in Brolga Street, was purchased from Ernest and Emma Culliford and in 1925 the Imperial Hotel was constructed. In 1926 a fire swept through Quilpie and destroyed the Quilpie Hotel. A new Quilpie Hotel, known as The Brick was constructed on the site. In October 1934 the Club Hotel was leased from Castlemaine Perkins Brewery and later purchased in 1965. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Politician and former Premier of Queensland, Sir Arthur Hunter Palmer, ca. 1870
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits premiers administrators politicians Palmer, Sir Arthur Hunter (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Son of Lieutenant Arthur Palmer, R.N., and his wife, Emily Hunter, Arthur was born in Armagh, Ireland, on 28 December 1819 and was educated at Youghal grammar school. He emigrated to New South Wales in 1838, and for many years worked for H. Dangar on his stations, eventually becoming his general manager. He went to Queensland and took up land, and in 1866 was returned to Parliament as member for Port Curtis. On 2 August 1867 he became colonial secretary and secretary for public works in the R. R. Mackenzie (q.v.) ministry, and in September 1868 secretary for public lands. Mackenzie resigned on 25 November 1868 and Palmer went into opposition. On 3 May 1870 he became premier and colonial secretary and in July 1873 secretary for public works. His ministry was defeated in January 1874. During his term of office acts were passed which led to much development on account of new railways. Palmer was colonial secretary and secretary for public instruction in the McIlwraith (q.v.) ministry which came into power in January 1879, but resigned these positions on 24 December 1881 to become president of the legislative council. He remained in that position until the end of his life. On several occasions he was administrator of the government between 1881 and 1898. He died at Toowong, Queensland on 20 March 1898, after a long illness. He married Miss C. J. Mosman in 1865, who died in 1885, and was survived by three sons and two daughters. He was created K.C.M.G. in 1881. (Information taken from: Project Gutenberg of Australia Internet database 2005, retrieved 19 September 2005, from <http://gutenberg.net.au/dictbiog/0-dict-biogP-Q.html>) Photographers: Mr & Mrs Oswald Allen, 360 George Street, Sydney.

records.dc:title: Daniel Edward Evans and J. Deakin at an EDCO (Evans Deakin and Company) picnic at Lone Pine, 1930
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: suits (clothing) hats ties bow ties engineers Brisbane - Fauna Reserves - Lone Pine, 1930 Evans, D. E. (Daniel E. ), 1885 - 1951 Evans Deakin & Co. Ltd. Brisbane (Qld.) Picnic grounds--Queensland--Fig Tree Pocket Wildlife refuges--Queensland--Fig Tree Pocket
records.dc:description: EDCO picnic in November 1930. Founders D.E. Evans and J. Deakin. (Description supplied with photograph) In 1910 Daniel Edward Evans, aged 25 and Arthur Deakin, aged 23, opened a small business in Edward Street as suppliers of engineering equipment. They acquired their first workshop in 1913. In July 1915 Evans joined the Australian Imperial Force as a lieutenant in the 2nd Divisional Engineers and served in Egypt and France. By the time his active service was terminated by wounds in February 1918 he was a major. In 1924 Evans became lieutenant-colonel commanding the 5th Division, Australian Engineers, and in 1930 colonel commanding the 11th Infantry Brigade. The engineering business, carried on during the war by Deakin, had prospered. Evans started a new workshop making small pieces of equipment in an outbuilding of his Coorparoo home in 1919. A larger establishment was bought in 1922. A new large workshop built at Rocklea for structural steel and railway-engine repairs in 1926 was ready to manufacture the steel work for the Story Bridge in 1933. Evans was in uniform again at the outbreak of World War II as chief engineer, Northern Command. In addition he established the Evans Deakin shipyard at Kangaroo Point. Evans retired in 1948 and died of cancer in Brisbane on 1 December 1951. (Information taken from: Australian Dictionary of Biography Online Edition, 2006, retrieved 23 March 2009, from <http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A080470b.htm>)

records.dc:title: Settee made for Rosenstengel home, 1930's
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture making couches furniture upholstery Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958. Settee made for Rosenstengel home, mid 1930s. Embroidered upholstery from 'Lee of Birkenhead'.

records.dc:title: Sketch by Paula Rosenstengel for an Ed Rosenstengel designed interior
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture making upholstery paintings grandfather clocks Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958. Paula Rosenstengel, the daughter of Edmund Rosenstengel, was born in Toowoomba in 1920. She studied art at All Hallows School where she was taught by William Bustard. After leaving school, she worked for a time sketching ideas for rooms incorporating the furniture designs of her father. After a period studying art in England, Wales, Italy and France in the late 1940's she returned to Brisbane to begin a fruitful period during which she was inspired by the Queensland landscape.

records.dc:title: Brisbane Exhibition Building on Gregory Terrace, Bowen Hills
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: brick buildings brickwork architectural features towers domes arches Brisbane - Buildings - Exhibition Building Bowen Hills (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Exhibition building was erected in 1891, being designed by the architect G. H. M. Addison and incorporating a T-shaped building, accommodating an exhibition hall, concert hall and basement dining room. The foundation stone was laid on 25 April 1891 and the entire building was completed by August of the same year. The building was brick with a corrugated iron roof. The glazed bricks were locally manufactured by James Campbell. In 1900 the Queensland Museum decided to move to and adapt the Exhibition Hall for a museum, after twenty years in a smaller purpose built building in William Street (which became the State Library). Alterations included the construction of a gallery within the main hall, addition of a line of windows in the main northern wall and the modification of the basement dining rooom into offices, preparation and storage spaces. The Queensland Museum moved into new premises in the South Bank precinct in 1987. (Information taken from: Queensland Heritage Register, retrieved on 21 December 2004 at <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600209&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Staff from Rosenstengel's furniture factory, Brisbane, 1926
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture making furniture factories factory workers Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958. Staff lined up in front of Rosenstengel's furniture factory in 1926. Bill Harley, standing at the far right in the back row, was Rosenstengel's foreman for over 30 years. Colin Frank Ashby is pictured fifth from the left in the front row.

records.dc:title: Exterior view of Kedron Lodge, Kalinga
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses Gothic revival (architecture) gardens windmills architectural features Brisbane - Residences - Kedron Lodge Kalinga (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Exterior view of Kedron Lodge, 119 Nelson Street, Kalinga, with windmill in the grounds. The building is a rare example of a substantial Colonial Gothic house built in stone in the early 1880s by Christopher Potter and John Petrie for Judge Alfred James Lutwyche (1810-1880), Queensland's first Supreme Court judge. Kedron Lodge is a large two-storeyed dwelling of twenty rooms beside Kedron Brook. Built of sandstone from John Petrie's Albion Quarry, its irregular silhouette is created by several steeply pitched gable roofs and five brick chimneys. Decoration includes traceried bargeboards, window mouldings and the castellated parapet and mouldings on the ground floor faceted bay. The unshaded windows are multi-paned sash. A string course delineates the two floors. The entrance porch leads to a large square-shaped front hall which gives access to the cedar staircase and the cellar. The hall terminates at a longitudal gallery or hallway that connects the rear wings. (Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency, 2007, retrieved 30 March 2007, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600238&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Anglican Church Grammar School ca. 1924
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:subject: private schools post-and-rail fences schools & colleges East Brisbane (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Poul C Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps. Looking up from Norman Creek at some of the original buildings including the Club Hut on the left and the Main House.

records.dc:subject: botanical gardens floods ships rivers Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Poul C. Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps. Several ships were left high and dry in the Botanical Gardens after the floodwaters in the Brisbane River receded.

records.dc:title: Wilston House at 47 Watson Street, Newmarket, ca. 1881
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: Colonial architecture brick houses architectural features verandas Newmarket (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: This brick residence, designed by Brisbane architect James Cowlishaw, was constructed ca. 1876 for William Wilson, a mercantile and insurance broker and later Brisbane representative for the Adelaide Milling Company. He was also a member of the Queensland Legislative Council from 1874 to 1878. The suburb of Wilston derives its name from this residence, which for many years was a prominent landmark in the Newmarket-Wilston district.

records.dc:title: Botanist Mr Frederick Manson Bailey
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, P.
records.dc:subject: portraits beards hairstyles men's clothing and accessories Bailey, Frederick Manson (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Born in London ca. 1827, Frederick Bailey arrived in Australia from England in 1839. He settled in South Australia with his family before moving to Queensland in 1861 where he set up a nursery in Edward Street, Brisbane. He later joined the staff of the Queensland Museum and in 1881 was appointed Botanist for Queensland. He published his most famous work Queensland Flora consisting of six volumes, over a period of time from 1899 to 1902 which still remains the standard reference on the subject. Frederick Bailey died in 1915. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: View of the main street of Winton, Central Queensland
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: views unsealed roads shops Winton Winton (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Winton is located in Central Queensland, 1400km North West of Brisbane. It is the major town in a cattle and sheep raising region. Originally known as Pelican Waterhole, it was renamed Winton by Robert Allen, the first postmaster. The town of Winton was gazetted in 1879. Winton is best known as the place where Banjo Paterson wrote Waltzing Matilda, and the first performance of that song. (Information taken from Walkabout website, retrieved 12 July 2007 from http://walkabout.fairfax.com.au/theage/locations/QLDWinton.shtml)

records.dc:title: Palmerin Street residence in Warwick, Queensland, 1932
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses verandas balustrades drives Warwick - Residences, 1932 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Possibly the home of G. P. Barnes, the mayor of Warwick. This asymetrical bungalow-roofed house is complemented by a decorative balustrade around the front verandah and lattice work on the side verandah. A curved driveway leads to the front entrance steps. Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from: M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: Exchange Hotel, William Street, Kilcoy, ca. 1919
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns architectural features Kilcoy - Hotels - Exchange Hotel, ca. 1919 Kilcoy (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Kilcoy is north-west of Caboolture on the DAguilar Highway, just north of Lake Somerset and at the base of the Conondale Range. The area was first settled in 1841 by Scottish migrants who cleared land on the upper reaches of the Sandy and Kilcoy Creeks to run beef and dairy cattle. Timber felling and milling was also important in the early development of the town, which was established in the 1890s and originally known as Hopetoun. The Exchange Hotel appears to have commenced trading in Kilcoy, then known as Hopetoun, about 1902. It is still trading in 2007 but the building was extremely altered in the 1920s. (Information supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Aerial photograph of the Brisbane residence, Whinstanes in Hamilton, ca. 1945
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: aerial photographs roads & streets timber house drives houses Brisbane - Residences - Whinstanes Hamilton (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: In the 1880s Mr A. B. Webster acquired the land and built an imposing residence, which he named Whinstanes. When he died in 1925 the RC Sacred Heart Sisters purchased the property and conducted a boarding school for young boys there until 1942, when they had to vacate because the buildings were required by the army. After the war, the property was sold to the Augustinian Fathers who conducted Villanova College on the site from 1948 until 1953. In 1954 Villanova College moved to new premises in Coorparoo and the Augustinians sold the Whinstanes land and buildings to a developer who demolished the buildings, including the magnificent Webster residence, and erected factories on the land. Whinstanes was located on the eastern side of College Street at Hamilton. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Murgon's first bank, the Queensland National Bank, in Lamb Street, 1914
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: banks weatherboard buildings shop verandas architectural features men's clothing and accessories military uniforms hats Murgon - Banks - Queensland National Bank, 1914 Murgon (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The first European settlers arrived in the Murgon area in 1843, taking up land which is now known as Barrambah Station. Murgon derived its name from a lily pond located on Barambah Station. The rich and fertile land was used for agriculture and dairying. Logging was another prosperous industry. The town itself didn't start to develop until the early 1900s. Large properties were divided into smaller allotments, and the local population increased. The town was surveyed and the sale of these lots took place in 1906. A butter factory was opened in 1913 and a grain shed was built the following year. (Information taken from: Murgon Shire Council, retrieved on 9 March 2005 at <http://www.murgon.qld.gov.au/history.htm>)

records.dc:title: Warwick Railway Station during the visit from His Royal Highness, Edward, Prince of Wales, 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments railway stations royal visits architectural features cars soldiers Australian flags British flags Warwick - Royal Visits, 1920 Warwick (Qld.) Railroad stations--Queensland--Warwick Royal visitors--Queensland
records.dc:description: Warwick Railway Station during the visit of the His Royal Highness, Edward, Prince of Wales, on 26 July 1920 . Prince Edward visited Warwick for about an hour, on Monday 26 July, 1920. He arrived at Warwick by train at 3pm, and was greeted by the Mayor, Alderman R. E. Gillam. A band played the National Anthem and the Prince was escorted through the main entrance of the railway station to where returned soldiers were drawn up in files. He passed here and there through the ranks, shook hands with one or two of the men and chatted for an instant before passing onto another. He then stepped into the waiting car and was driven down Grafton Street to the cheering of the people. The car took him to the Rotunda in Leslie Park where the Prince received a gift of painted views of Warwick. The Prince was then driven back to the railway station. The train moved off to the accompaniment of ringing cheers, with the Prince standing on the platform at the rear of the rail car. (Information taken from: The Warwick Daily News, 27 July 1920, p. 5.)

records.dc:title: People's Palace, Brisbane, 1932
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: private hotels street scenes motor vehicles buildings, structures & establishments architectural features Brisbane - Hotels - People's Palace Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The People's Palace was built on the corner of Ann and Edward Streets by the Salvation Army in 1910-1911. It was a temperance hotel built near the Central Railway Station in Brisbane. The rules were strictly no alcohol or gambling. It existed to provide affordable accommodation for working class people. In 1913 two more storeys were added to the original three storey building. (Information taken from: The Department of Environment and Heritage registers and inventory website, 2006, retrieved 13 February 2007 from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index>)

records.dc:title: Canon Jones Memorial Chapel ca. 1924
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:subject: private schools chapels schools & colleges East Brisbane (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Poul C Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps. Anglican Church Grammar School chapel at Oaklands Parade, East Brisbane. The foundation stone for the Canon Jones Memorial Chapel was laid by Archbishop Gerald Sharp on 1 August 1923. Built by Thomas Keenan out of red bricks on what was then the highest part of the school grounds, the building was capable of accommodating 250 boys. It was dedicated by the Archbishop on 4 May, 1924.

records.dc:title: Christmas card issued by Greenfield and Barraclough, Brisbane Opticians, ca. 1893
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, P. C.
records.dc:subject: Christmas cards portraits advertisments sketches Brisbane - Firms - Greenfield & Barraclough, ca. 1893 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Promotional Christmas card sent to clients. Greenfield and Barraclough,the opticians operated out of George Street, Brisbane. The front of the card features a sketch of human eye and photographs of Queensland legislators and ministers. On the reverse of the card it reads: 'Messrs Greenfield & Barraclough present their compliments to their many Patrons, and hope for a continuance of past favors. We wish to specially impress on the minds of all customers that we have a complete record of all past examinations, from which orders can be made up at any time. Intending country clients write us for particulars of our Self-Testing method before giving orders for spectacles locally. Our speciality is Sight Testing and Scientific Spectacle Adjusting.' (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: HRH Edward, The Prince of Wales leaving Albert Square, Brisbane, July 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: royal family crowds military uniforms street scenes Brisbane - Royal Visits, 1920. Windsor, Edward, Duke of, 1894-1972. Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: HRH The Prince of Wales leaving Albert Square, Brisbane, after laying the second foundation stone at the new Town Hall, 29 July 1920. The Prince, who arrived for the ceremony shortly before 1 o'clock, had come from Parliament House after an investiture and levee in the Legislative Council Chamber. Crowds enthusiastically acclaimed him as he was driven through the city in a motor car via George, Queen and Albert Streets to the Square. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Garden of Poulsen residence
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:subject: gardens gardening rivers domestic architecture Dutton Park (Qld.)
records.dc:description: On the opposite side of the river is what is now known as St. Lucia - the site of the University of Queensland. Poul C. Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps.

records.dc:title: Harald Ingemann Jensen, ca. 1910
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits men's clothing and accessories furniture mugs bags Jensen, Harald Ingemann (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Harald Jensen, 1879-1966, was a geologist and social pamphleteer. He was born in 1879 at Aarhus, Jutland, Denmark. Migrated to Queensland with his parents at age six, attended public schools at Irvinebank and Caboolture. Later won a scholarship to the Brisbane Boys' Grammar School. Graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree with honours in geology in 1904. He died after accidental electrocution in Brisbane on 13 July 1966. (Taken from: Australian Dictionary of Biography, v. 9, 1891 - 1939) Photographer: Sidney Riley, Queen Street, Brisbane.

records.dc:title: Cosmopolitan Hotel, Palmerin Street in Warwick, ca. 1874
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: baustrades hotels & taverns brick buildings Warwick - Hotels - Cosmopolitan Hotel, ca.1874 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This hotel was first licensed to Charles Colas in the year ending 30th June, 1873. In addition to offering first class accommodation, the hotel also provided good paddocking on the hotel grounds. Like most of the bigger hotels of that time, the Cosmopolitan made a part of its premises available for travelling salesmen to conduct their business when in town. (Description supplied with photograph.) Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: Rural scene at Stanthorpe in 1909
records.dc:creator: Connah, T. W.
records.dc:subject: country scenes panoramic views Stanthorpe - Views, 1909 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp', meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Queensland Club Hotel, Brisbane, ca. 1887
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns architectural features fences Brisbane - Hotels - Queensland Club Hotel, ca. 1887 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Situated in Mary Street, this building was brought from W. A. Brown in 1860 by the Queensland Club, for use as clubrooms. It was considerably altered to this appearance before 1870. Following the opening of the new clubrooms at the corner of Alice and George Streets in 1884, the building was licensed as the Queensland Club Hotel. It was de-licensed in 1941. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Scene at the laying of the foundation stone for Brisbane City Hall, July 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: royal family crowds hats foundation stones mayors Brisbane - Royal Visits, 1920 Windsor, Edward, Duke of, 1894-1972 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Scene at the laying of the foundation stone of the future Brisbane City Hall, on the corner of Albert Square and Adelaide Street, 29 July 1920. In the centre of the official dais was the foundation stone, hewn from granite quarries at Greymare in the Warwick district. The Mayor presented the Prince with an inscribed trowel made of 15-ct Queensland gold with a Queensland Maple handle, in which was set a Queensland opal. (Description supplied with photograph.) His Royal Highness Edward, Prince of Wales became King Edward VIII. After abdicating in 1936 he became the Duke of Windsor.

records.dc:title: Phaff's Hotel, Bowen, ca. 1908
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns Bowen - Hotels - Phaff's Hotel, ca. 1908 Bowen (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This hotel appears to have originally been known as the Railway Hotel in Dalrymple Street, which first appears in listings ca. 1889. J. F. Phaff, former proprietor of Cooke's Hotel apparently took over ca. 1899-1900, and by 1904 the hotel was known as Phaff's Hotel. After 1912, when Phaff relinquished the license, the hotel was again known as the Railway. After 1923, the hotel disappears from the records under that title. (Description supplied with photograph, with information obtained from Queensland Post Office Directories and Pugh's Almanacs.)

records.dc:title: Panoramic view of Stanthorpe, ca. 1925
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: panoramic views buildings, structures & establishments Stanthorpe - Views Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp', meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.) In the foreground of the photograph is Shafer & Wilson Garage and a granite quarry can be seen in the centre.

records.dc:title: Fountain in the garden of Wynberg, New Farm, ca. 1940
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses fountains gardens Brisbane - Residences - Wynberg, 1940 New Farm (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Wynberg, Brunswick Street, New Farm. The official residence of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Brisbane from early 1928, when it was leased to the Church and occupied by Archbishop James Duhig. The property was purchased by the Archbishop on behalf of the church on 06 December 1932. (Description supplied with photograph) Wynberg's white marble fountain is a replica of a work by Verrocchio and was presented to Archbishop Duhig as a mark of appreciation from the Italians in Australia. (Information taken from: The Courier Mail, 20 February 1937)

records.dc:title: Jessie Poulsen , ca 1885
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:subject: women's clothing & accessories interior decoration bustles parasols
records.dc:description: Studio portrait of Jessie Poulsen (nee Hill), the daughter of the Mayor of South Brisbane and the wife of photographer Poul C. Poulsen, founder of Poulsen Studios in Brisbane. Poul Poulsen was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers, in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps.

records.dc:title: Interior view of Bellisvick, Ipswich
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furnishings rooms furniture pictures architectural features Ipswich - Residences - Bellisvick Ipswich (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Bellisvick, Nicholas Street, Ipswich was purchased in 1864 by Joseph Foote (youngest brother of John Clarke Foote) and Mrs Foote, nee Esther Trotman. Their daughter Miss Esther Evelyn Foote (later Mrs Percival Pitman Outridge), who was born 27 March 1871 and died 19 February 1939, sits by the piano. Bellisvick was demolished in September 1975. (Description supplied with photograph) The room is wallpapered and has large pictures hanging from the walls. The end wall has a row of timber doors. Furniture of various kinds fills the room while surfaces are covered with books and china.

records.dc:title: North Brisbane School of Arts Building, ca. 1877
records.dc:creator: Tissington, G. A.
records.dc:subject: official buildings schools of arts horsedrawn carts streetlights buildings, structures & establishments architectural features Brisbane - Buildings - North Brisbane School of Arts, ca. 1877 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The North Brisbane School of Arts was established in 1849 and its first premises were located on the corner of Queen and Creek Streets. This building was erected in 1864/6 and was designed by Cowlishaw and Taylor. In December 1872, the Queensland National Bank purchased the North Brisbane School of Arts land and building for the sum of 8000, as the site for its new head office. However the School of Arts leased back the building until they moved into their new building in Ann Street in 1878. During the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, the School of Arts played an important role in the cultural life of the community, providing a library for members, conducting public lectures, and providing organised classes in a wide variety of subjects. (Information taken from: Queensland Heritage Register, retrieved on 3 December 2004 at <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600072&back=1>)

records.dc:description: A new cake kitchen in connection with the Soldiers' Sock and Comfort Fund was recently opened in Margaret Street, Toowoomba. records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments fences panoramic views Stanthorpe - Views, 1926 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp', meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: James Taylor
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits suit (clothing) bow ties politicians mayors graziers squatters Taylor, James (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: James Taylor was born in 1820 in England. He arrived on the Darling Downs in 1848, becoming H. S. Russells head stockman at Cecil Plains Station, a partner in 1856 and sole proprietor in 1859. By 1880 the 147,310 acres of freehold carried nearly 100,000 sheep and was supplemented by Dunmore, Goodar and Coomrith stations on the Western Downs and Mount Marlow on the Barcoo River. From 1860 to 3 May 1870 Taylor was the member for the Western Downs in the Queensland Legislative Assembly. He was a member of the Legislative Council from November 1871 until 1893. He was a director of the Queensland Brewing Co., the Queensland Mercantile and Agency Co., and the Land Bank of Queensland. Taylor was elected Mayor of Toowoomba in 1890. He was concerned with the Toowoomba School of Arts, Toowoomba Grammar School, the Queensland Turf Club, the Royal Agricultural Society, the Queensland Club and the Brisbane Diocesan Synod. Taylor was a generous donor to the local Anglican parishes. He is also remembered for importing the first steam-driven sawmills to Toowoomba and was a significant land holder in the town, including the Royal Hotel. He was a member of the Union Club which commissioned the building of Clifford House in Russell Street in 1860. Taylor and his family took up residence in the building in 1870. Survived by his wife Sarah, ne Boulton, whom he had married on 16 February 1850, four of his five sons and three daughters, he died at at Clifford House, Toowoomba on 19 October 1895 and was buried in the local cemetery. (Information taken from: Australian Dictionary of Biography, Online Edition, 2006, retrieved 30 June 2007, from <http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A060264b.htm>

records.dc:title: Two boys standing in front of St. Paul's Church of England Stanthorpe, ca. 1914
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches religious structures & establishments timber buildings picket fences children's clothing Stanthorpe - Churches - St. Paul's Church, ca. 1914 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The church was dedicated on 15 October 1905. Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:description: Poul C Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps.

records.dc:title: William Butler Memorial, Kilcoy, ca. 1927
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: monuments & memorials Kilcoy - Monuments & Statues, Butler Memorial, 1927 Kilcoy (Qld.)
records.dc:description: William Butler was appointed manager of Kilcoy Station in 1871, which was owned by the Hope family. He was associated with Kilcoy for the next 50 years. In 1882 the Hopes returned to England, leaving Kilcoy Station under Butler's supervision. At Kilcoy, Butler established excellent relationships with local Aborigines. After his death a Kilcoy street was named after him and this monument erected in his honour.

records.dc:title: Samuel Grimes and family
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits women's clothing & accessories men's clothing and accessories Grimes Family (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: On Samuel's right is Annie, with Francis seated on his left, and George leaning on the veranda rail. In the front from the left are: Douglas, Ernest, Gertrude, Lillian, Grace and William. (Description supplied with photograph) The Grimes family arrived in Brisbane on the 'Chasely' one of Dr Lang s boats, in 1849. They came with their families from Warwickshire in England. William Grimes began as an assistant in the drapery department of Richardson s store until it became Grimes and Petty and moved to Queen Street. Other family members bought a ridge in Dutton Park to grow potatoes and maize. They were experienced farmers and by 1857 George Grimes had started an arrowroot farm called 'Fairfield'. At one time the Grimes family owned most of Fairfield as farms and a dairy. George and Samuel Grimes owned three farms in the Yeerongpilly/Tennyson area. In 1862 they were experimenting with arrowroot production there and by 1863 they had an arrowroot mill and drying kiln. They grew sugar and had a sugar mill, Coongoon, until it burnt down in 1876. In 1878, George and Samuel bought nine acres at Yeronga, which were transferred to William in 1885. Here they built 'Kadumba' which was designed by prominent architect Richard Gailey. The family were staunch Baptists. In 1862 they gave land for a Mission Hall, which was built in 1865, and later became the Fairfield Baptist Church. William Grimes was the first to hold services there. Samuel went on to become a member of the Legislative Assembly and George was the second chairman of Stephens Shire. William Grimes died in 1896 and George Grimes died in 1910. (Information taken from: Internet database, retrieved 31 May 2005 from <http://www.brisbites.com/suburbView.asp?suburb=124&topic=5>)

records.dc:title: Peaceful setting for St. Catherine's Church of England Girls' College, March 1933
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: schools & colleges buildings, structures & establishments unsealed roads Stanthorpe - Schools and Colleges - St. Catherine's Curch of England Girls School Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp', meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Poul C. Poulsen
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:subject: men's clothing and accessories Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:description: Poul C Poulsen, photographer and founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882, he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers, in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps.

records.dc:title: S. G. Benson, R. A. M.
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits suits (clothing) organists Benson, S. G. (Portraits)
records.dc:description: S. G. Benson was born in London, England, in 1857. After important posts as organist in several English Cathedrals, Benson came to St. James, Townsville. Here he opened the first pipe organ in North Queensland. After his work in Townsville and Charters Towers, Benson came to Brisbane where he was successively organist of the Fortitude Valley Wesleyan Church, St Paul's Presbyterian Church and the Albert Street Wesleyan Church. He was one of the musical directors of the International Exbitition in 1897 and gave daily recitals on the grand organ. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: View of Warwick looking north from the vantage point of the Town Hall, 1897
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: town views timber buildings roofs stone buildings roads & streets parks Warwick - Views, 1897 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Looking north, in the foreground is the intersection of Palmerin and Fitzroy Streets. The western side of Palmerin Street features the bank of New South Wales, Leslie Park and Cunningham Park. In the right hand corner stands the Australian Joint Stock Bank and the manager's residence. The opposite corner was occupied by J. A. Gorry's Saddlery. Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from: M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: French imported housing project at Zillmere, Brisbane, 1952
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses suburbs public housing views housing estates Zillmere (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Queensland Housing Commission and French contractors built 886 houses at Zillmere under the Imported Houses (Commonwealth Sponsored) Scheme. The Zillmere project, using labour recruited overseas, was the first estate to be built under the Scheme. The French partners were the firm Messrs. Lcorch Freres and Schroth, Paris (Information taken from: Queensland. Housing Commission, Report of the Commissioner, 1952). This view includes some of the Housing Commission homes at Zillmere which can be compared with the non-Housing Commission homes in image numbers hch00001 and the Housing Commission homes in hch00004. records.dc:title: Harald Ingemann Jensen having a conversation with his dentist, ca. 1910
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits men's clothing and accessories advertising signs desks books Jensen, Harald Ingemann (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Harald Jensen, 1879-1966, was a geologist and social pamphleteer. He was born in 1879 at Aarhus, Jutland, Denmark. Migrated to Queensland with his parents at age six, attended public schools at Irvinebank and Caboolture. Later won a scholarship to the Brisbane Boys' Grammar School. Graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree with honours in geology in 1904. He died after accidental electrocution in Brisbane on 13 July 1966. (Taken from: Australian Dictionary of Biography, v. 9, 1891 - 1939) Photographer: Sidney Riley, Queen Street, Brisbane.

records.dc:subject: schools & colleges schoolchildren groups (people) children's clothing hats Stanthorpe - Schools & Colleges - Stanthorpe State School, 1933 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:description: The gardener is hard at work in the grounds of Poul Poulsen's home. Poul C. Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882 he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps.

records.dc:title: First Queensland Government House, Adelaide Street, Brisbane
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: official buildings architectural features official residences Deanery (St. John's Cathedral, Brisbane, Qld.) Official residences--Queensland--Brisbane Governors--Dwellings--Queensland--Brisbane Parsonages--Queensland--Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The first Queensland Government House was built by Andrew Petrie for Dr. William Hobbs. It was occupied by Sir George Ferguson Bowen from his arrival on 10 December 1859 until 26 April 1862. The Proclamation of the separation of Queensland from New South Wales was read from the balcony of this residence. The property was acquired by the Church of England in 1899 and has been the Deanery since 1910. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Edward, Prince of Wales on a racehorse in Brisbane Queensland
records.dc:creator: Bell, Charles Bertram
records.dc:subject: horseracing horse riding horses Ascot (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Prince of Wales during his visit to Queensland. He arrived on 26 July and stayed until 5 August 1920. During that time he travelled by train from the New South Wales border, visited Warwick and Ipswich and many smaller centres around the south east. He attended a Shakespearian Ball held by the Shakespeare Society at John Bridge and Co.'s Wool Store in Helen Street, Newstead near the Bulimba Reach of the Brisbane River and many other official functions. (Information taken from Visit to Queensland of His Royal Highness The Prince of Wales, 26th July to 5th August, 1920 Working Programme.)

records.dc:title: Victoria Bridge after the 1893 flood
records.dc:creator: Poulsen, Poul C., 1857-1925
records.dc:subject: floods buildings, structures & establishments bridges sailing boats rivers Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Looking across towards the city from South Brisbane with the ruined Victoria Bridge in the foreground and the Windmill on the hill in the distance. Poul C. Poulsen, founder of the Poulsen Studios in Brisbane, was born in Denmark in 1857 and arrived in Sydney in 1876. In 1882 he moved to Queensland and was later joined by his sisters and brothers from Denmark. He opened his own studio at no 7 Queen Street in 1885 and later opened branches, run by his brothers in other Queensland towns. Poulsen vigorously advertised constant improvements and modernisation in his studio and in the service he provided. His sons and grandson followed in his footsteps.

A lady with three dogs sits on the verandah beside her collection of plants arranged on a prominent tiered stand.

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: railway bridges railway workers stone pylons railway lines
records.dc:description: Railway bridge under construction on the Stanthorpe Extension. The bridge was 70 feet in height and comprised one 100 foot and four 50 foot spans. The columns were constructed out of heavy masonry net in cement concrete foundations and filled in with the same material.

records.dc:title: Palmer River coach outside the Sovereign Hotel in Cooktown
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: balustrades horses hotels & taverns stagecoaches horseriding Cooktown (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Sovereign Hotel was originally constructed in 1874, at the port end of Charlotte Street, it was on of the first double storey buildings in Cooktown. On 28 January 1882 The Queenslander newspaper stated that Cobb & Co. coaches left Cooktown every Satruday at 8am and left Maytown (Palmer River) on the return journey on Tuesdays at 10am. They arrived back in Cooktown on Thursdays at 6.00am. (Information taken from A Chronicle of Cooktown and District, 2005 retrieved 12 January 2006, from http://www.users.bigpond.com/leslieslegends/Notes/Cooktown/cooktownchron.htm)

records.dc:title: Saddle and harness maker J. O'Hare's timber building in Moreton Street, Eidsvold, ca. 1910s
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber buildings buildings, structures & establishments advertising signs shop verandas saddleries Eidsvold - Firms - O'Hare, Saddle and Harness Maker Eidsvold (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Norwegian named town in the Burnett River country of central Queensland. The area was first settled in 1848 by the Scottish Archer brothers, Charles and Thomas, who migrated to Australia from Norway, to where their parents had moved in 1825. Eidsvold s halcyon days followed the discovery of gold in 1887 and the region kept producing ore for more than 60 years before it ran out. Today, the town the Archer brothers named for their parent s adopted homeland is the commercial centre for prime beef producers. The nearby Waruma Dam is a playground for swimmers, sailors and water-skiers. (Information taken from: Internet travel database 2005, retreived 13 May 2005, from <http://www.travelmate.com.au/Places/Places.asp?TownName=Eidsvold_%5C_QLD>)

records.dc:title: Commercial Bank building in Bourbon Street, Bundaberg, ca. 1905
records.dc:creator: Skyring, C. F.
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features banks ironwork slate roofs Bundaberg (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Photographs selected from an album presented to the Hon. J. G. Appel, MLA, Home Secretary, by the North Bundaberg Progress association as a mark of their appreciation of his efforts in connection with the abolition of the toll on the Burnett Traffic Bridge, 1st January 1913. (Description supplied with album) Building features two storeys with wrought iron balustrades, decorative roof trims and a widow's walk. Iron work decorates the fascia below a slate tiled roof. A curved picket fence surrounds the building, connecting with the front entrance verandah.

records.dc:title: Barnes Auto Dodge tow truck, ca. 1938
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: motor vehicles tow trucks Dodge (trucks) Motor Trucks 1930-1940 Dodge trucks Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Dodge chassis with a 3 ton load capacity. Unusual streamlined art deco styling and signwiriting. Barnes Auto had a business slogan, 'We Never Sleep' as it was a 24 hour service. Tow truck was built and owned by Luton White, the founder of Barnes Auto. The business was originally a service station in Adelaide Street and subsequently a towing and salvage company based in Spring Hill. The tow truck was used for towing light commercial vehicles and passenger cars.

records.dc:title: All Hallows' Convent, Brisbane, 1889
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features religious structures & establishments convents schools & colleges boarding schools Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Two years after the separation of the colony of Queensland from New South Wales, All Hallows' School for Girls was founded by the Sisters of Mercy and the first pupil was enrolled as a boarder in December 1861. All Hallows' was the first secondary school for girls in Queensland. The school is situated high on the hill in Ann Street and is clearly visible from the Story Bridge and the Brisbane River. Initially, the school was located at St Stephens but in 1863 Bishop Quinn purchased a new home for the order. 'Adderton' built by John Petrie for Dr George Fullerton was located at Duncans Hill and was bought for the sum of 6000 pounds. 'Adderton' still forms part of the central section of the present convent and the new school was called All Hallows. It is believed that the name came from the All Hallows college in Dublin. (Information taken from Brisbites website 2006, retrieved 12 April 2006, from < http://www.brisbites.com/mayneView.asp?ID=6>)

records.dc:title: Brisbane Boys' Grammar School, 1889
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features schools & colleges Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Public fundraising enabled the establishment of Brisbane Grammar School in 1868. It was Brisbane's first Grammar School. In 1868 Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh, laid the foundation stone at the School's original site in Roma Street. The school opened in February 1869 with ninety-four students and four masters under the leadership of Headmaster, Thomas Harlin. In 1881, the school was moved to its present site at Gregory Terrace and the magnificent Neo-Gothic style Great Hall and classrooms were opened that year. The building was designed by architect James Cowlishaw. With the opening of the Boarding House in 1886, the school became one of the first to provide unified boarding facilities on site. (Information taken from Brisbane Grammar School website, 2006, retrieved 12 April 2006, from: <http://www.bgs.qld.edu.au/welcome/history.htm>)

records.dc:title: Founding parishioners of the Russian Orthodox Church of Saint Nicholas, Woolloongabba, Brisbane, 1937
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches religious structures & establishments religious groups Russians children Brisbane - Churches - Woolloongabba - Russian Orthodox Church of Saint Nicholas, 1937 Russian Orthodox Church of Saint Nicholas (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Russian Orthodox parish in Woolloongabba was established by white Russians fleeing the Russian revolution. Initially they worshipped in St Thomas' Anglican Church in South Brisbane. In 1925 they purchased a cottage in Vulture Street and converted it into a church. In 1935 the old church was moved to the back of the block so that a new church could be built. This was the first purpose built Russian Orthodox Church constructed in Australia. The new church was designed by Mr Gregory Mekhonoshin and given to a firm of Architects, Messrs. Cavanagh and Cavanagh, for final professional preparation. The new church was completed in 1936. (Information taken from: Galina Zakrjevsky, History of St Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral in Brisbane, Australia 1923-1993, 1997)

records.dc:title: Leo Hotel moving along Lime Street, Clermont, 1917
records.dc:creator: Pullar, Gordon C.
records.dc:subject: floods flood damage building removal hotels & taverns lagoons Clermont (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Following the flood that virtually destroyed Clermont in December 1916, the people of Clermont voted to move the town to higher ground. 'Each building was raised on jacks and timber rails laid underneath it and for about one hundred metres ahead. A steam traction engine then winched the building slowly along the track. When it came to the end of the track, the rails were collected and laid down in front for another hundred metres. ...Considering the size of the task of moving a hotel, the procedure did not take long. The contract to move the Grand Hotel was signed in June 1917, the steam engine began its work on 16 August and by 15 September the Grand was opposite its new site on the corner of Capella and Daintree Streets. While the hotel was 'on the road', the boarders had their meals served in the dining room as usual and slept in their rooms each night. The other hotels were also moved in this way, although the Commercial, being so large and built in an 'L' shap plan, was sawn in half and moved in two sections. Other buildings moved by traction engine included several houses and Griffin's store.' (Information taken from: G.C. Pullar, A shifting town : glass-plate images of Clermont and its people, 1986). Town Hall in background and lagoon on the left.

records.dc:title: Rainworth, residence of the first Surveyor General of Queensland, ca. 1895
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: suburbs houses timber buildings fences eucalypts Brisbane - Suburbs - Rainworth, ca. 1895 Rainworth (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The photograph was probably taken by Sir Gregory, ca. 1895. (Description supplied with photograph.) Rainworth House was a simple wooden house on about 26 acres of land in Barton Street. Gregory established an orchard and added numerous outbuildings including a barn, storehouse, meathouse and forge and grazed cattle on what is now Norman Buchan Park. He also purchased adjacent portions of land to the south and west of the property and these were fenced and left with native timber. (Information taken from the Queensland Placenames Board's Brisbane Suburbs and Localities held at the John Oxley Library)

records.dc:title: Marr's Guest House situated on Tank Street, Brisbane, ca. 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: ironwork architectural features private hotels verandas Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This guest house was owned and run by the Marr family from 1914-1918. The architecture is part of the Victorian Filigree style used between 1840 - c.1890. Style features intricately textured verandah balustrades. The predominance of this lacework was due to the mass production of decrative cast-iron components. (Description supplied from Apperly, Irving & Reynolds, A Pictorial Guide to Identifying Australian Architecture, 1994.)

records.dc:title: Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade officers posing in front of their Head Office in Wharf Street, Brisbane, 1901
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: ambulances official buildings ambulance officers horses buggies uniforms Ambulances - Brisbane, 1901 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Ambulance officers are pictured with their sulkies drawn by white ponies, and their wheeled litters. Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade in Brisbane was established in 1892. In 1897 the first of the white ponies and sulkies were purchased, but the sulky only provided the means of getting to the place of the accident; the patient was still transported by pushing the litter. The first motor vehicle was placed in commission in May 1909. (Information taken from: E. Bradley, History of the Queensland ambulance, 1999?)

records.dc:title: P. J. Whelan's Dispensary in Palmerin Street, Warwick, ca. 1873
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: chemist shops dentists timber buildings hotels & taverns unsealed roads Warwick - Firms - Warwick Dispensary ca. 1873 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The dispensary was owned by P. J. Whelan, chemist and dentist. In his advertisements in the local papers he offered among other goods: Weston's Wizard Oil, Magic Pills, Whelan's Celebrated Black Oils and Rossetter's Hair Restorer. As a dentist he promised that , 'teeth will be extracted, scaled and stopped'. To the right of the photograph is the Criterion Hotel. (Description supplied with photograph.) Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from: M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: Doctor Thomas Lane Bancroft, 1860-1933
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits entomology doctors (medical) scientists medical sciences & health Bancroft, Dr. Thomas
records.dc:description: Portrait of Doctor Thomas Bancroft, medical naturalist, born on 2 January, 1860, the son of Dr. Joseph Bancroft who arrived in Brisbane in 1864. Thomas graduated from Edinburgh University in 1883, to come back to Queensland and practise in Ann Street, Brisbane from 1889-1894. Thomas Bancroft served as a quarantine officer for the Port of Brisbane, government medical officer in 1908 and medical officer on Palm Island in 1930. He undertook many other investigations ranging from blood parasites of birds to Aboriginal food-plants and hybridization of cotton. Absorbed in natural history, he made an indirect contribution to knowledge over a wider field on which he published eighty-four papers. He died on the 12 November, 1933. (Information taken from Australian dictionary of biography, v.7, 1992)

records.dc:title: Manning family on the steps of Milton House, 1868
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses architectural features shingle roofs chimneys verandas families Brisbane - Residences - Milton House, 1868 Milton (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Front view of Milton House showing the Maning family on the front steps, 1868. Milton House was erected in 1852 or 1853 for retired Queen Street chemist Ambrose Eldridge.This hip-roofed house is Colonial Georgian in style and plan, having a typical front doorway with segmented sidelights with arched fanlight, and a symmetrical arrangement of rooms radiating off a central hallway on each floor. The ground floor has wide, open verandahs on three sides. Two service rooms run across the rear of the house incorporating pavilion wings off the side verandahs. The walls are of brick, which is lime rendered and jointed to give the impression of stone. A three-roomed cellar is constructed of rough rubble walling, and entered by steps on the south side of the verandah. The roof is covered in shingles. Milton House was originally built as a homestead, high on the riverbank overlooking the surrounding property and survives sufficiently in form, feature and material, to be important in demonstrating the principal features of Colonial Georgian architecture adapted to local climatic conditions, notably through the inclusion of verandahs and french doors on three sides. (Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency, 2007, retreived 3 April 2007, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600253&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Portrait of William Knox D'Arcy, ca. 1907
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits businesspeople D'Arcy, William Knox British Petroleum Company
records.dc:description: William Knox D'Arcy was born at Newton Abbot, Devonshire, England in 1849. At the age of 17 years he and his family migrated to Australia. He studied law, and when qualified joined his father's practice. He was a practising solicitor at Rockhampton when the Morgan brothers took up mining leases on Ironstone Mountain (later named Mount Morgan) in 1882. In 1886 the 'Mount Morgan Gold Mining Company' was formed, and D'Arcy became a director and major shareholder of the company. William Knox D'Arcy died in 1917. Mount Morgan did not benefit in any way from the fortune he made at Mount Morgan. The only remembrance this town has of D'Arcy is a street named after him. (Information taken from:Shire of Mount Morgan , 2002, retrieved 15 April 2003, from http://www.mountmorgan.com/dArcy.html)

records.dc:title: Moving the 'Mephisto' tank to the Queensland Museum, Bowen Hills, Brisbane, 1919
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: tanks (vehicles) museums steamrollers street scenes cars horsedrawn vehicles Brisbane - Suburbs - Bowen Hills, 1919 Queensland Museum Bowen Hills (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The 'Mephisto' is the sole surviving German tank from World War I, captured by Australian troops in 1918 and brought back to Australia as a war trophy in 1919. This image shows the Mephisto being manoeuvred through the gates of the Queensland Museum on 23 August 1919. 'Around midnight on 21/22 August two Brisbane City Council steam-rollers departed from the wharf with Mephisto, travelling on its own tracks, in tow. Some difficulty was experienced when turning corners and the tank damaged the road surface in several areas. But the entourage eventually arrived at the old Museum building in Gregory Terrace about 11am '...amidst excitement, and in the presence of a fair crowd...' and Mephisto was placed in a prominent position in front of the building.' (Information taken from: M. Whitmore, Mephisto : A7v sturmpanzerwagen 506 : a history of the sole surviving First World War german tank, c1989)

records.dc:title: St Joseph's Convent School in Chinchilla, Queensland, 1938
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: porticos Art Deco architecture convents schools & colleges Chinchilla - Schools and Colleges - St. Joseph's Convent School,1938 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Front brick wall and entrance to the two-storey art deco building. A breezeway allows glimpses through into the grounds. Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Rover Tin Mines at Stanthorpe, ca. 1912
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: mines mining tin mines miners pumps Stanthorpe - Mines - Rover Tin Mines, ca. 1912 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Parliament House, Brisbane, ca. 1870
records.dc:creator: Daintree, Richard, 1832-1878
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments parliamentary buildings Victorian architecture botanical gardens parks Parliament House (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Richard Daintree collection held in the John Oxley Library has many unidentified images. If you are able to assist with identification, please click on the Feedback tab. Richard Daintree, geologist and photographer, was born in 1832 in Huntingdonshire, England. He matriculated at Christ's College, Cambridge in 1851 and in 1852 joined the gold rush to Victoria. Unsuccessful as a prospector he became assistant geologist in the Victorian Geological Survey until 1856. On a visit to England he became interested in photography and when he rejoined the Geological Survey in 1859 he pioneered the use of photography in field-work. In 1864 he became a resident partner with William Hann in pastoral properties in the Burdekin country of North Queensland. There he was able to indulge his passions for both photography and prospecting. When the pastoral boom collapsed he used his knowledge to open up goldfields at Cape River (1867), Gilbert (1869) and Etheridge in 1869-70. Daintree advocated a geological survey of Queensland and when it began in 1868 he was geologist in charge of the northern division until 1870. In that year he made some of his finest photographic studies. In 1871 his collection of photographs and geological specimens formed the mainstray of Queensland's contribution to the Exhibition of Art and Industry in London. He was sent to England as commissioner in charge of this display, although much of it was lost when the ship carrying Daintree and his family was wrecked. In London he was appointed Queensland's agent-general in 1872. Due to ill health Daintree resigned in 1876 and died in Kent on the 20th June, 1878. His photographs , taken under difficult conditions by the cumbersome wet-plate process, are superb specimens of the art and present a vivid picture of early settlement in Queensland. Front view of Parliament House from the Botanical Gardens, featuring the entranceway, windows , facade and roofs. The first sitting of Parliament in this building took place at 12 o'clock on 4 August, 1868 (Information taken from: Centenary : first meeting in new Parliament House, George Street, Brisbane, Queensland, 4th August, 1868, <1968>).

records.dc:title: Railway bridge and the town of Stanthorpe, ca. 1882
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: towns town views panoramic views railways railway bridges post-and-rail fences Stanthorpe - Views, ca. 1882 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. The railway was built and opened in 1881 to connect Stanthorpe and Warwick. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: touring cars motor dealers motorcycle shops unsealed roads Warwick - Firms - J. Abood Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Motoring enthusiasts gather outside the Downs Motor Garage in their open top tourers. Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: Aerial view of Charleville, 1934
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: aerial views buildings, structures & establishments roads & streets Charleville (Qld.)
records.dc:description: London- Melbourne Centenary Air Race was sponsored by Sir Macpherson Robinson as part of the Melbourne Centenary celebrations in October, 1934. The Centenary Air-Race was one of the greatest air races in aviation history, according to some. The route stretched over 19 countries and seven seas. Five compulsory stops were designated for both divisions. Between the five stops (Baghdad, Allahabad, Singapore, Darwin and Charleville) pilots could select their own route. Winners of the speed section of the race were British fliers C.W.A. Scott and T Campbell-Black in a red DeHavilland 88 Comet, named Grosvenor House. They reached Melbourne in two days 23 hours 18 seconds, with a total air time of 71 hours. Winner of the handicap section, and second fastest with an air time of 81 hours 10 minutes, was the Dutch airliner Uiver (Stork). Crewed by Parmentier, Moll, Prins and Van Brugge and carrying three passengers, the Douglas DC2 was entered by KLM airlines and showed that passenger air travel could be comfortable, safe and reliable. This photograph is taken from an album titled 'Centenary Air Race Photographs, Charleville' compiled by the Courier-Mail & Telegraph, Queen Street, Brisbane, December 1934. Photographs were taken when pilots stopped at Charleville on their way to Melbourne.

records.dc:title: G. Meek's house in 24 McGregor Terrace, Bardon
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: domestic architecture houses buildings by condition, construction or location Brisbane - Suburbs - Bardon, 1951 Bardon (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The image shows architect G. Meek's house in Bardon, still under construction. The house, designed to suit the land, stands at 43 feet above ground level at the back and only 15 feet above footpath level at the front. A concrete catwalk leads from the street into the lounge and vestibule, situated in the peak of the high pitched roof. On the floor below are the kitchen, dining room, bathroom and maid's room, while the next floor down contains three bedrooms and a sleep-out. The pitch of the roof was so steep that the tiles had to be fixed by hand from the inside and pinned with special clips. The estimated final cost at the time the photograph was taken was 3, 500. The suburb of Bardon was named after Bardon House, built by Joshua Jeays, an architect and a partner of Andrew Petrie in the construction of the Petrie Terrace Goal. Bardon House was named after Jeays' birthplace, Bardon Hill in Leicestershire, England. Joshua Jeays was an alderman of the first Municipality of Brisbane from 1859 to 1864, when he became the Mayor. The area that is now Bardon was first surveyed on 12 November, 1862. This was followed by the sale of the land, with only three buyers showing interest: Joshua Jeays, Francis Lyon and Edward Wyndham Tufnell. Tufnell became the first Anglican Bishop of Brisbane. Another person of influence to live in Bardon was Sir Charles Lilley, the editor of the Moreton Bay Courier and Premier of Queensland from 1868 to 1870. Sir Charles played an important role in the introduction of the Education Act of 1875, which provided free education to all. Landmarks of Bardon include a 70 feet high water tower built in 1927 to supply water to the higher parts of Brisbane, and 'Fernberg' house, now the Government House. The house was built in 1865 by J. C. Heussler and purchased by the government in 1910. Another famous feature of Bardon is Ithaca Creek, named after the birthplace in Greece of Lady Bowen, wife of the first governor of Queensland. (Information taken from: Queensland Place Names Board, Brisbane suburbs and localities; ourbrisbane.com : your city online, retrieved 7 June 2004, from <http://www.ourbrisbane.com/living/suburbs/bardon/history/>)
