records.dc:title: 1902 Trevethan, the first car made in Queensland.
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: motor vehicles men's clothing and accessories gardens Motor Vehicles 1900 - 1910 Trevethan automobile Toowoomba (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Trevethan is a motor buggy based around a 1 1/2 horsepower, single cylinder De Dion engine, and is thought to be the first Queensland-made car. It was made by Thomas and Walter Trevethan in their Coach Works in Neil Street, Toowoomba in 1901-2, largely to their own design. In 1903 it was driven down the Toowoomba range and on to the coast at Redcliffe, north of Brisbane. The lack of suitable oils for engine lubrication and a primitive transmission brake which operated through a chain to the rear wheels made such extended journeys a great challenge. The car was seriously damaged after being charged by bullocks in 1915 and subsequently spent many years lying in sheds and under houses, but has now been restored by veteran car enthusiast Ross Flewell-Smith, and is part of the RACQ's 'Bulldust to Bitumen...and Beyond' touring exhibition. The photo caption reads: 'The car in Toowoomba after completion'.

Winners of the speed section of the race were British fliers C.W.A. Scott and T Campbell-Black in a red DeHavilland 88 Comet, named Grosvenor House. They reached Melbourne in two days 23 hours 18 seconds, with a total air time of 71 hours. Winner of the handicap section, and second fastest with an air time of 81 hours 10 minutes, was the Dutch airliner Uiver (Stork). Crewed by Parmentier, Moll, Prins and Van Brugge and carrying three passengers, the Douglas DC2 was entered by KLM airlines and showed that passenger air travel could be comfortable, safe and reliable. This photograph is taken from an album titled 'Centenary Air Race Photographs, Charleville' compiled by the Courier-Mail & Telegraph, Queen Street, Brisbane, December 1934. Photographs were taken when pilots stopped at Charleville on their way to Melbourne.

records.dc:title: Bowlers on the green at Stanthorpe Bowls Club, 1933
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: bowlers bowling clubs (places) bowling greens uniforms Stanthorpe - Bowling Greens, 1933 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Wooden framed upright tub chair manufactured by F. H. Byrne, Upholsterers, Brisbane
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture furniture factories upholstery fabric design chairs Fortitude Valley (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The premises of F. H. Byrne, Upholsterer, existed on Brunswick Street in Fortitude Valley between Amelia and Leichhardt Streets (later St Paul's Terrace) between 1925 and 1932 (Information taken from: Queensland Post Office Directories, 1925-1932). The firm was established by Byrne and Keeper in 1913 and continued in various forms until 1960, when FH Byrne died and the company was taken over by his daughter and Alistair Macpherson. The company was wound up in 1984. This wooden framed tub chair upholstered in a moire stripe material, was photograhed in the driveway beside the factory.

records.dc:title: Crowds line the street outside the church for the funeral for Judge Hugh Macrossan, Brisbane, June 1940
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: funerals funeral processions motor vehicles crowds judges architectural features buildings, structures & establishments Macrossan, Hugh Denis (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Hugh Denis Macrossan (1881-1940), after a distinguished scholastic career, was called to the Queensland bar in 1907. He was M.L.A. for Windsor 1912-15, was appointed a judge of the supreme court of Queensland in 1926, and chief-justice in May 1940. He died after a short illness on 23 June 1940, having established a high reputation both as a lawyer and as a judge. He acted as host to the Papal delegates when the foundation stone of the Holy Name cathedral was laid, and was made a Knight of St Gregory. (Description taken from: Internet Project Gutenberg database 2005, retrieved 9 November 2005, from: <http://gutenberg.net.au/dictbiog/0-dict-biogMc.html>)

records.dc:title: Baroona, a residence in Paddington, Brisbane, 1886
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: brick houses architectural features gardens verandas Brisbane - Residences - Baroona, 1886 Paddington (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Taken from Baroona's garden looking towards the drawing room. An unidentified man is standing on the grass by the verandah. The original residence of Baroona on Howard Street, Paddington was designed by Benjamin Backhouse and built in 1866 for William Draper Box. Baroona is a single storey brick building with a corrugated iron gabled roof and verandahs on all sides. The gables have timber finials and decorative bargeboards with the eastern bay gable featuring timber fretwork. (Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency database, 2007, retrieved 5 April 2007, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600289&back=1>)

records.dc:title: General Hospital as seen from the driveway, Warwick, ca. 1897
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hospitals drives gardens horsedrawn vehicles architectural features verandas Warwick - Hospitals - General Hospital, ca. 1897 Warwick (Qld.) Hospitals--Queensland--Warwick
records.dc:description: This second general hospital was opened in 1884 in Locke Street, on Wallaby Hill (subsequently known as Hospital Hill) and was a two storey building containing 40 beds. At that time it was considered the best in Queensland. The hospital was governed by a committee who set rules and regulations for the hospital. Among other rules were the ones for not admitting patients for various reasons, including children under 5 years of age, old people, confinement cases and people suffering from incurable diseases. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Cooper's garage in Moreton Street, Eidesvold, 1930
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: motor vehicle repair shops commercial establishments advertising signs motor vehicles fences Eidsvold - Firms - Cooper's Garage, 1930 Eidsvold (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Garage is owned by M. Cooper and he advertises motor and general repairs. There are signs on each door advertising sales of Buick, Oakland and Oldsmobile cars. The buildings are constructed of corrugated iron with iron roofs. Two cars are parked outside the garage and a man is standing in the doorway next to another vehicle. Both buildings have numerous advertising signs painted on them. Eidsvold is a Norwegian named town in the Burnett River country of central Queensland. The area was first settled in 1848 by the Scottish Archer brothers, Charles and Thomas, who migrated to Australia from Norway, to where their parents had moved in 1825. Eidsvold s halcyon days followed the discovery of gold in 1887 and the region kept producing ore for more than 60 years before it ran out. Today, the town the Archer brothers named for their parent s adopted homeland is the commercial centre for prime beef producers. The nearby Waruma Dam is a playground for swimmers, sailors and water-skiers. (Information taken from: Internet travel database 2005, retreived 13 May 2005, from <http://www.travelmate.com.au/Places/Places.asp?TownName=Eidsvold_%5C_QLD>)

records.dc:title: Workers clear a cyclone damaged house at Mackay, 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage clutter (household) houses accidents & disasters relief workers cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts relief workers clearing a house demolished by the cyclone.

records.dc:title: Main street in Mount Isa with Smiths Hotel on the left, ca. 1936
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: main streets hotels & taverns shops streetscapes motor vehicles trucks Mt. Isa (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Mount Isa streetscene with cars and trucks passing in front of the Pioneer Store, and the butcher's shop. Caption under the photograph reads, ' Smith's Hotel on the corner. Beer, 1/- a mug, Lager, 3/- a bottle. Costs a lot of money to get merry in this town.' (Description supplied with photograph.) Mount Isa is situated next to the Selwyn Ranges on the Leichhardt River. Mount Isa owes its prosperity to the huge Mount Isa Mine, the worlds largest single producer of copper, silver, lead and zinc. In 1923 John Campbell Miles found a silver-lead ore outcrop and made a claim for two mining leases. Mount Isa Mines took over operations in 1924. This rich deposit is still producing high volumes of ore and is classed as one of the world's great mines. (Information taken from Queensland Holidays website, 2006, retrieved 5 April 2006, from http://www.queenslandholidays.com.au/outback/mount_isa.cfm)

records.dc:title: Rev. William Smith, Primitive Methodist Church minister
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits ministers of religion clerical collars coats Smith, Rev. William (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Rev. William Smith was born 17 February 1851 at Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, England. He married Elizabeth Postle on 18 March 1878 at Great Yarmouth and they arrived at Brisbane on 4 July 1878 aboard the ship Egmont. Rev. Smith conducted his first religious service in Australia on 6 July 1878 at the Leichhardt Street Primitive Methodist Church at Spring Hill, a suburb of Brisbane. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:creator: Ham, Thomas
records.dc:subject: churches chapels panoramic views Brisbane - Churches - St Stephen's Church (Catholic), 1862 St. Stephen's Church (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: St Stephen's church situated in Elizabeth Street is in the centre of a panoramic view of Brisbane in 1862. Behind the church is the Brisbane River and Kangaroo Point. The panorama was taken from near the Observatory on Wickham Tce. The church was designed by Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin, an eminent British architect, and built by Andrew Petrie during 1849 and 1850. The chapel was opened for public worship on 12 May 1850.

records.dc:title: View over Paddington Cemetery towards Milton, Brisbane, ca. 1870
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: graves burial grounds houses churches Brisbane - Cemeteries - Paddington Cemetery, ca. 1870 Lang Park Stadium (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: View from Petrie Terrace, possibly near Cricket Street, looking over the Paddington Cemetery towards the suburb of Milton and the residence known as 'Bishopsbourne' (1868). Small timber framed houses with shingle roofs appear in the foreground. Paddington Cemetery dated from 1844 and was closed to further burial in 1875. The mortuary chapel visible in the centre of the photograph was converted to a church in 1873, and was demolished when Christ Church (Milton) was constructed in 1874-76. Lang Park was established on this site in 1913, later known as Suncorp Stadium (Description supplied with photograph).

records.dc:title: Refugee tents at Mackay after the cyclone, 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage tents groups (people) views accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts some people posing in front of their tent shelters that have been erected at the showgrounds in the aftermath of the cyclone.

records.dc:title: Small businesses in Biloela, 1949
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: cars (Holden) shops streets Biloela - Streets, 1949 Biloela (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Main Street of Biloela in 1949. (Description supplied with photograph) Biloela is in the fertile Callide Valley, 142 km south-west of Rockhampton. The name of the town comes from an aboriginal word for 'white cockatoo'. The Gangulu tribe inhabited the area before European settlement. Ludwig Leichhardt explored the region in 1844. Today, water from artesian bores irrigates crops of lucerne and cotton. The area is rich in coal with the Callide power stations producing about 20 per cent of Queensland's electricity. Beef production is also a major industry and the Biloela meat works are the third largest in Queensland. (Information taken from: Banana Shire Council database, 2002-2004, retrieved 25 August 2004, from http://www.banana.qld.gov.au/index.php/3 , Walkabout database http://www.walkabout.com.au/locations/QLDBiloela.shtml and Explore Australia, 2003.)

records.dc:title: St Brigid's Church, Rosewood, 1910
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches religious ceremonies crowds horsedrawn vehicles buildings, structures & establishments Rosewood - Churches - St Brigid's Roman Catholic Church, 1910 Rosewood (Qld.)
records.dc:description: St Brigid's Catholic Church, Matthew Street Rosewood, (in the Ipswich district of Queensland), was blessed and dedicated by Archbishop Duhig while he was Bishop of Rockhampton. (Description supplied with photograph) In this image, a well-dressed crowd is assembled in front of the church. Various buggies and other carriages are stationed around the grounds. This large elaborate wooden church was built in 1909-1910 and replaced an earlier, smaller St Brigid's Church. It was designed by Reverend A Horan of the Ipswich parish and built under the supervision of builder and contractor, RJ Murphy. The foundations of the second church were blessed on 13 December 1908 and the building was opened on 13 February 1910 by Bishop Duhig. Rosewood was the first country place in which, as a priest, Bishop Duhig had celebrated Mass.

records.dc:description: John Leahy was born in Schull, County Cork, Ireland in July 1854. Waterson, Australian National University Press, Canberra, 1972 , page 105 - 106.] The funeral procession is passing the Courier building at 11:50am. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Houses in O'Connell Street, Kangaroo Point, ca. 1917
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features retaining walls Brisbane - Suburbs - Kangaroo Point, ca. 1917 Kangaroo Point (Qld.)
records.dc:description: These houses were originally built on the site of new high rise developments including Silver Quays, near Dockside. The redevelopment of the old Evans Deakin Shipyards into the Dockside development in the late 1980s was the beginning of further residential redevelopment in Kangaroo Point, particularly in those areas where maritime activities once took place. During the past 10 years, new stages of the Dockside development have been added as well as other residential projects including Silver Quays.

records.dc:title: Map of Brisbane, 1844
records.dc:creator: Gerler, C.F.
records.dc:subject: maps drawings Brisbane - Maps, 1844 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Map of Brisbane drawn by C. F. Gerler. This basic map has a numbered list of forty-eight locations in the bottom right corner. The list corresponds to places and residences on the map. The locations are represented by hand drawings of houses and other buildings with the numbers next to them. Trees, roads, and rivers are have also been included as a decorative flourish. Caption: Brisbane in 1844. Map legend : 1. Andrew Petrie, 2, Handel, cattle drover, 3. Savory (the only baker), 4. Bensteads, sawyers, 5. T. Richardtson (the only general store), 6. Convict Barracks, 7. W. Kent (druggist shop), 8. Fitzpatrick (the first Chief Constable), 9. The Lock-up, 10. The Constable's place (only two in all), 11. Slate's Post Office (old), 12. Slate's Pineapple Garden, 13. Church of England, 14. The Hospital, 15. Mort, milkman. 16. Wright's Hotel, 17. General Cemetery, 18. Tread and Windmill, 19. Edmonston.s Paddock, 20. Old R. Jones, 21. Dr. Simpson (the first Commissioner), 22. Old Major Prior, 23. The Gaol, 24. Skyring's Beehives (soft goods shop), 25. Hayes, milkman, 26. Brothers Fraser (first houses), 27. Catholic Church, 28. McLean's Blacksmith's Shop, 29. Edmonston's butcher, 30. Bow's Hotel. 31. Taylor Shappart, 32. Montifeur (a financier), 33. W. Pickering, 34. Sergeant Jones, 35. Soldiers' Barracks, 36. Officer de Winton, 37. Commission Stores, 38. Queen's Wharf, 39. Captain Wickham's office, 40. Commissioner T. Kent, 41. Commissioner's Garden, 42. Captain Coley, 43. Government Gardens, 44. Father Hanley (the only priest), 45. Saw Pits, 46. Queen Street, 47. The Boat House and Boatman's House, 48. The First Tombstone (two graves). (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Kuranda (ship) at Port Douglas wharf, ca. 1917
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: ships groups (people) wharves marine & waterway places & structures Port Douglas - Jetties, ca. 1917 Port Douglas (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Kuranda (ship) is docked at the Port Douglas wharf and is viewed from the bow. The bridge, funnel, masts and decking is well featured in this image. A military officer accompanies a group of women along the railway tracks near the wharf buildings. The image is part of a Kodak postcard. The reverse of the postcard reads: Front Street, Mossman, North Queensland, 5th Sept. 1917. Dear Ivy, I never got a letter from you yesterday but a postcard came from Minnie to Anne. This is the Kuranda at the Port Douglas Wharf. Mabel Lematy is still in the hospital. It has been very dry up here in these last few weeks. The members of the Gayndah Band sent Gil a gold medal for helping them while the show was on. Be sure to write every week or else I'll start and write to Kate. Where is Tango now? From your loving sister, K. D. Jones.

records.dc:title: Cyclone damaged ships at Mackay, 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage ships accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a consequent tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts some beached and damaged ships.

records.dc:title: Cyclonic conditions on the Pioneer River, Mackay, 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage views rivers ships wharves accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a consequent tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts the Pioneer River buffetted by strong winds.

records.dc:title: Float mock up of the hospital ship Kanowna, a float in the Armistice Parade, Brisbane, 1918
records.dc:creator: Shale, John F.
records.dc:subject: floats Kanowna (Ship) processions street scenes Stereoscopic views Parades--Queensland--Brisbane World War, 1914-1918--Queensland--Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The TSS Kanowna was used as a hospital ship during World War I. The TSS Kanowna was requisitioned in June 1915 and proceeded to England where she was converted to a hospital ship with accommodation for around 450 patients. For the next three years she transported sick and wounded between England and Australia as HMAS Kanowna. This float depicts the ship as it was during the war, with sailors in uniform riding on the deck. It was part of the Armistice Procession in Brisbane during the peace celebrations at the end of the war.

records.dc:title: Uniformed officers attend to a female survivor of the Camp Mountain railway disaster, 1947
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: railway accidents railways injured people officials uniforms Railways - Accidents - Camp Mountain, 1947 Railroad accidents--Queensland--Camp Mountain Camp Mountain (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Survivor Mrs T. McLean of Edith Street, Newstead, gets a cup of tea after she has been extracted from the wreckage. She was imprisoned for six hours. (Information taken from: Courier Mail, 06 May 1947, p. 3) This railway accident occurred near Camp Mountain on Monday 05 May 1947. The picnic train organised by the Customs and Excise department's social club, left Brisbane with nearly 500 women and children at 8.55 am. At 9.55 am, the leading carriage jumped the rail in a cutting a few miles on the Brisbane side of Closeburn, where the picnic was to have been held. The accident, 13 1/2 miles from Central Station, killed 15 and injured 30. It was Queensland's worst rail disaster. An emergency rescue gang was formed within a few minutes from local farmers and shopkeepers. (Information taken from: Courier Mail, 06 May 1947, p. 1)

records.dc:title: Cyclone damage to the Tay (ship) at Mackay, 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage ships trees rivers accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a consequent tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts the grounded Tay (ship).

records.dc:title: Internal view of the Regent Theatre, Brisbane, ca. 1955
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: theatres & cinemas stages (theatres) interiors (buildings) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Hoyts Regent Theatre was built in 1929 and was designed by Charles Hollinshed. The style was both Spanish Gothic and Empire period. Seating at that time was 2,583 patrons and the auditorium was cooled by the first air conditioning in Queensland. Four crystal chandeliers hung from the dress circle ceiling. A WurliTzer Opus no. 2040 theatre organ was installed to entertain the patrons during interval. in the 1950s the organ was dismantled and sold to a private person in New South Wales, but it is now reinstalled in the Queensland Art Gallery's Cinematheque. The Regent is located in Queen Street Mall, between Albert and Edward Streets and today operates as a cinema complex. The downstairs Cinema One is a likeness to the original theatre.

records.dc:title: Nurses having a tea break at St. Helen's Private Hospital, South Brisbane, ca. 1905
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hospitals nurses uniforms St. Helens Methodist Hospital (Brisbane, Qld.) Portraits, Group South Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: St. Helen's Hospital was established by Dr. Charles Kebbell in 1896. It was housed in a two storey building previously known as the St Helen's Boarding House on the river side of Peel Street, South Brisbane. In 1949 the hospital was acquired by the Methodist Church and became known as the St Helen's Methodist Hospital. In 1969 it was decided to move the hospital to the 'Moorlands' estate on Coronation Drive, Milton, to become part of the planned Wesley Hospital. The St Helen's site was eventually bought by the State Government for the building of a new State Library of Queensland.

records.dc:title: Cyclone damaged ships in the Pioneer River at Mackay, 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage ships rivers views trees accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a consequent tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts ships on the Pioneer River, Mackay, during the storm.

records.dc:title: George Thorn
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits premiers Thorn, George (Portraits)
records.dc:description: George Thorn junior, was born in 1838 in Sydney New South Wales, eldest son of George, storekeeper and pastoralist, and Jane, nee Hancock. He married Celia Constance Maud Uniacke and had two sons. George Thorn was MLA West Moreton 3 May 1860 - 3 April 1861, 2 July 1867 - 18 November 1873; Fassifern 25 November 1873 - 8 January 1874; MLC 9 January 1874 - 13 June 1876; MLA Ipswich 23 June 1876 - 20 February 1878; Nothern Downs 17 April 1879 - 7 September 1883; Fassifern 9 August 1887 - 10 May 1888, 6 May 1893 - 11 March 1902. George Thorn was PMG and government representative in LC 9 January 1874 - 5 June 1876; PMG and Secretary Public Works and Mines 7 November 1877 - 6 February 1878; and member of the Roy. Com Liquor Traffic 1900. He died 15 January 1905 in Booval Ipswich, Queensland. (Information taken from: D. B. Waterson, Biographical register of the Queensland Parliament 1860 - 1929, 2001)

records.dc:title: Port Office in Edward Street, Brisbane, 1889
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: official buildings architectural features fences chimneys Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Port Office was built in 1879-80 to a design by the Colonial Architect, F. D. G. Stanley. The contractor was John Petrie. In 1885 a two-storey extension was constructed at the rear of the building. In 1929 the building was extended to provide more space for the Department of Labour which had occupied the building since 1906. In 1988 the property was leased to a private company and the building became part of the Heritage Hotel complex. Extensive renovations were undertaken, including the removal of all post 1880 additions, and the addition of the end balconies which were shown on the Colonial Architect's original plans. (Information taken from: Queensland Heritage Register, retrieved on 14 December 2004 at <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600088&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Brisbane River in flood, looking towards South Brisbane, 1893
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: views floods buildings, structures & establishments ships Brisbane River (Qld.)
records.dc:description: February 4 1893 saw the highest floods on record in Brisbane and elsewhere; 6ft water in Edward Street at the Courier Buildings, hundreds of houses washed down river, trees uprooted and shipping torn from moorings. The shores of Moreton Bay were strewn with wreckage. On 5th Indooroopilly Bridge was washed away; pm the 6th the northern end of Victoria Bridge disappeared; flood waters rose at Brisbane to 23 feet 9 inches above mean spring tide and 10 feet over the previous highest flood mark (1890). Similar disaster befell other towns where bridges and houses disappeared by the hundreds; at Gympie many of the mines were blown up; much loss of life reported particularly from Ipswich. Rainfall at Crohamhurst, head of Brisbane water was 105 inches between 1st January and 11th February. A second flood almost reaching the level of the first was experienced on the 19th, a lesser one having prevailed on the 13th. South Brisbane was without fresh water for some days and the whole of Brisbane practically in darkness at night. A very large relief fund (70,000 pounds) was established, subscriptions in money and in kind arriving from England as well as from the other colonies. Information taken from : Queensland State Archives database, 2004 - 2006, retrieved 11 January 2006, from <http://www.archives.qld.gov.au/exhibitions/virtualexhibition/images/1893introduction.asp>)

records.dc:title: Parked cars and a section of the crowd at the Stanthorpe Showgrounds in February, ca. 1932
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: showgrounds crowds cars men's clothing and accessories women's clothing & accessories Stanthorpe - Showgrounds, ca. 1932 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Newly built Stanthorpe Showgrounds hosted its first show on 25 May 1905. In 1875 the Border Agricultural, Horticultural and Mining Society was established. This society determined that all shows were to be held on the Queen's Birthday. (Information taken from: Harslett & Royle, They came to a plateau : the Stanthorpe Plateau. Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Township of Stanthorpe looking from Mount Marloe
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: panoramic views granite rocks Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:creator: Laurie, W. G.
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features main streets clock towers Townsville (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Sir Robert Philp was a politician and Premier of Queensland from 07 December 1899 until 17 September 1903. He was also a founder of the large North Queensland company of Burns, Philp, based in Townsville. This album was presented to Sir Robert by the People's Progressive League, on his retirement from politics. All photographs in the album were taken by W. G. Laurie and have been surrounded with hand drawn and coloured frames created by Charlotte Cameron.

records.dc:title: Yungaba Migrant Hostel, Ward Street, Rockhampton, 1956
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: migrant hostels gardens timber buildings Federation architecture Rockhampton (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Yungaba Migrant Hostel was constructed in 1890 as a private residence for John Fergusons daughter Catherine Jane Ferguson and her husband, solicitor, Charles Sydney Jones. It was originally named, Killin. Later appoximately 1949, the Queensland government purchased it to be used as offices but it became a Migrant Hostel for sponsored migrants arriving in Rockhampton during the post war period. Although alterations were made to accommodate the migrants, the original timber Queenslander had a large central entryway flanked by bay windows and encircling verandah. (Infomation taken from the EPA Heritage Register, 2005, retrieved 31 May 2006 from http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.)

records.dc:title: St. John's Church of England in Cairns, 1926
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches steeples stained-glass windows paling fences religious structures & establishments Cairns - Churches - St. John's Church of England, 1926 St. John's Church of England (Cairns, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The first timber St. John's Church of England in Abbott Street was erected in 1884 and destroyed by a cyclone in 1920. A new site was chosen for a more substantial building on the corner of Lake and Minnie Streets. The foundation stone of the new concrete church was set on the 27th June 1926 and the building was formally dedicated on the 23rd January 1927. A cyclone struck several days later with no damage to the new church. (Information taken from: C.F. Cusson, St. John's Church, Cairns: golden jubilee, 1927-1977, 1977) A sign on the front fence reads: 'New Church of St. John'.

records.dc:title: All that remains of Victoria Bridge at South Brisbane after the floods, February 1893
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: floods rivers bridges buildings, structures & establishments Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: February 4 1893 saw the highest floods on record in Brisbane and elsewhere; 6ft water in Edward Street at the Courier Buildings, hundreds of houses washed down river, trees uprooted and shipping torn from moorings. The Indooroopilly Bridge was washed away and the northern end of Victoria Bridge disappeared. Floodwaters rose at Brisbane to 23 feet 9 inches above mean spring tide and 10 feet over the previous highest flood mark (1890). A second flood almost reaching the level of the first was experienced on the 19th, a lesser one having prevailed on the 13th. South Brisbane was without fresh water for some days and the whole of Brisbane was practically in darkness at night. A very large relief fund (70,000 pounds) was established, subscriptions in money and in kind arriving from England as well as from the other colonies. Information taken from : Queensland State Archives database, 2004 - 2006, retrieved 11 January 2006, from <http://www.archives.qld.gov.au/exhibitions/virtualexhibition/images/1893introduction.asp>)
records.dc:publisher: John Oxley Library, State Library of Queensland

records.dc:title: Spectators watch as floodwaters threaten to wash away Victoria Bridge, Brisbane, 1893
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: floods bridges crowds ships rivers buildings, structures & establishments Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: February 4 1893 saw the highest floods on record in Brisbane and elsewhere; 6ft water in Edward Street at the Courier Buildings, hundreds of houses washed down river, trees uprooted and shipping torn from moorings. The Indooroopilly Bridge was washed away and the northern end of Victoria Bridge disappeared. Floodwaters rose at Brisbane to 23 feet 9 inches above mean spring tide and 10 feet over the previous highest flood mark (1890). A second flood almost reaching the level of the first was experienced on the 19th, a lesser one having prevailed on the 13th. South Brisbane was without fresh water for some days and the whole of Brisbane was practically in darkness at night. A very large relief fund (70,000 pounds) was established, subscriptions in money and in kind arriving from England as well as from the other colonies. Information taken from : Queensland State Archives database, 2004 - 2006, retrieved 11 January 2006, from <http://www.archives.qld.gov.au/exhibitions/virtualexhibition/images/1893introduction.asp>)

records.dc:title: Refreshments were available from the Royal Hotel at the Queensland Intercolonial Exhibition, 1876
records.dc:creator: Wright, G. P.
records.dc:subject: shows & exhibitions agricultural shows hotels & taverns restaurants, cafes etc. buildings, structures & establishments Brisbane - Showgrounds - Exhibition Ground, 1876 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Two views of the refreshment rooms erected by John A. Phillips, the proprietor of the Royal Hotel in Queen Street, Brisbane, to cater for visitors to the first National Agricultural & Industrial Association Intercolonial Exhibition at Bowen Park in August 1876. Instead of a tent or shed, Mr Phillips constructed a large building of timber and iron, with an extensive bar and luncheon tables capable of seating about 400 people. Customers enjoyed a 'handsome lunch', consumed what liquors they pleased, and paid as they left the rooms. (Information taken from The Brisbane Courier, 23 August 1876, p. 5)

records.dc:title: Ellenthorpe Steam Flour Mills in Warwick, ca. 1865
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: flour mills horses general stores chimneys Warwick - Flour Mills - Ellenthorpe Steam Flour Mills, ca. 1865 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This was the first mill in Warwick erected in 1861 by Charles Clark and James McKechie on the Condomine River, facing Wantley Street. Adjacent to the mill was a general store where the farmers could get goods as part payment for delivered grain. An early advertisement in the Warwick Argus 1860 reads: 'Gristing. The undersigned are prepared to grind wheat for anybody who will bring not less than 10 bushels. Chas. Clark & Co., Ellenthorpe Steam Flour Mills, Warwick' (Description supplied with photograph.) Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from: M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: Buildings in South Copperfield, 1876
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: town views street scenes unsealed roads buildings, structures & establishments Copperfield (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Copperfield was once a booming mining town and produced Queensland's first copper mine. The mine was the first to be worked commercially outside South Australia and also the first rich mine in Queensland. In 1862, a 10 feet high wall of solid copper ore was discovered at Copperfield. Mining continued until the 1880's when the best quality ore was mined out.Copperfield is located 5km south of Clermont in the Belyando Shire, North Queensland.

records.dc:title: Two women on the steps of the General Post Office, Brisbane, 1919
records.dc:creator: Thiel, F. W. (Frederick William)
records.dc:subject: women's clothing & accessories hats post offices Costume, 1910-1920 (Female adult) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Two women photographed standing on the steps of the Queen Street GPO during a World War I peace procession in 1919. The women are wearing similar outfits consisting of ankle-length, straight skirts, jackets and blouses with hemlines that drop at the back, and wide brimmed hats. The woman on the left is wearing a scarf over her hat, covering her face and neck. The woman on the right is carrying a handbag.

records.dc:title: St John's Anglican Pro Cathedral, William Street, Brisbane taken about 1895
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches bell towers Brisbane - Churches - St John's Pro Cathedral (Anglican), ca. 1895 St John's Pro Cathedral (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Probably taken from the second storey of the Treasury hotel (corner of Elizabeth and George streets) looking over what is now Queen's Park. St John's Pro Cathedral was erected between 1850 and 1854 by John Petrie and dedicated on 29 October 1854. Additions were made in 1868, directed by Benjamin Backhouse. The church was demolished in 1904.

records.dc:title: Wrecked steam locomotive after its boiler exploded, Brisbane, 1898
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: steam trains locomotives explosion damage railway accidents railways Railways - Accidents - Brisbane, 1898 Locomotive boiler explosions--Queensland--Brisbane Railroad accidents--Queensland--Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The boiler of this locomotive exploded on 2 December 1898 at Roma Street, Brisbane. The locomotive was an American built QGR Class A 12, No. 62, built by Baldwin Locomotive Works. Information about this locomotive can be found in the 1898 Votes and Proceedings of the Queensland Legislative Assembly volume 1 commencing on page 315. The Court of Enquiry into the explosion was recorded in the 1899 Votes and Proceedings of the Queensland Legislative Assembly. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Barolin Street, Bundaberg, ca. 1914
records.dc:creator: Blaikie, W.
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features clock towers verandas roads & streets Bundaberg (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Bundaberg is situated at the southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef. Four hours drive north from Brisbane, Bundaberg is located in the heart of a rich sugar and horticultural belt. Bundaberg is identified with the locally manufactured Austoft Cane harvesters and famous Bundaberg Rum. This photograph is part of a hand coloured publication titled 'Souvenir of Bundaberg', published by W. Blaikie, Bundaberg, ca. 1914.

records.dc:title: Funeral procession for the Monto air crash victims in Bundaberg, 1948
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: funeral processions street scenes military uniforms motor vehicles air accidents Americans in Queensland Bundaberg (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A twin engined United States Douglas Dakota transport plane crewed by four American airmen, was lost on its final leg from Ward's airfield in New Guinea to Archerfield in Brisbane, via Cairns, Townsville and Rockhampton on 21 November 1943. The plane loaded cargo in Townsville and mail in Rockhampton. After leaving Rockhampton the aircraft disappeared without trace. On 21 June 1948 a farmer found the wreckage in a gully on Magpie Station at Yarrol, in the Monto district of Queensland. The plane was carrying 4 American crewmen, 2 American military passengers and 7 Australian military passengers. The funeral in Bundaberg on 5 July 1948 was held for all 13 men found in the wreckage of the plane.

records.dc:title: Street in Dutton Park, Brisbane, 1943
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber houses picket fences power & telegraph poles shops advertisements suburban streets Brisbane - Suburbs - Dutton Park, 1943 Dutton Park (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Timber houses and a shop advertising Dr. Morse's Indian Root Pills are visible. The suburb of Dutton Park was originally known as Bloggo, which became corrupted to Boggo and thus gave the name to Boggo Road (now known as Annerley Road). The area was eventually renamed Dutton Park after Charles Boydell Dutton who was the Queensland Minister for Lands from 1883 to 1887. Originally the district was not popular with settlers because of early plans for the construction of the South Brisbane Cemetery and gaol. However the area eventually found favour due to its proximity to the city and the development of public transport. The South Coast Railway was built through the district and a station was opened at Dutton Park in 1884. Land was initially bought for farming, however residential development soon followed after the introduction of the tramline in 1908. (Information taken from: Queensland Place Names Board: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities, and Brisbites Suburban Sites, retrieved on 13 September 2004 at <http://www.ourbrisbane.com/living/suburbs/dutton_park/history/>)

records.dc:title: Brisbane Grammar School in Gregory Terrace, Brisbane, ca. 1883
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments schools & colleges architectural features Gothic revival (architecture) lithographs Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Photographs taken from an album of lithographic prints titled Views of Brisbane, printed by Gordon & Gotch, Brisbane, ca. 1883. Public fundraising enabled the establishment of Brisbane Grammar School in 1868. It was Brisbane's first Grammar School. In 1868 Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh, laid the foundation stone at the School's original site in Roma Street. The school opened in February 1869 with ninety-four students and four masters under the leadership of Headmaster, Thomas Harlin. In 1881, the school was moved to its present site at Gregory Terrace and the magnificent Neo-Gothic style Great Hall and classrooms were opened that year. The building was designed by architect James Cowlishaw. With the opening of the Boarding House in 1886, the school became one of the first to provide unified boarding facilities on site. (Information taken from Brisbane Grammar School website, 2006, retrieved 12 April 2006, from: <http://www.bgs.qld.edu.au/welcome/history.htm>)

records.dc:title: Museum building in William Street, Brisbane, ca. 1883
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments official buildings museums architectural features lithographs Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Photographs taken from an album of lithographic prints titled Views of Brisbane, printed by Gordon & Gotch, Brisbane, ca. 1883. This building was constructed between 1876 and 1879 as the first purpose-built home for the Queensland Museum. The building was designed by F. D. G. Stanley and was modelled on 16th century Italian architecture. It was completed and occupied early in 1879, but it soon proved inadequate for museum purposes. However it was not until 1899 that the museum moved to the former Exhibition building in Gregory Terrace. The building was later transformed into premises for the Public Library of Queensland, established in 1896. The library opened in the refurbished building in April 1902.

records.dc:title: Anzac Day celebrations in Mackay, outside the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, 1920-1930
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: banks customs houses military parades bands flags soldiers processions Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Commonwealth Bank was housed in the Customs House (pictured here) from 1921 to 1934, when the bank moved into the Australian Bank of Commerce building in Victoria Street. This Customs House, located at the corner of Sydney and River Streets, was completed in April 1902. The design of the building is attributed to J. S. Murdoch, District Architect with the Queensland Works Department. It was constructed by M. S. Caskie. The Customs House is a single storey brick building with a curved entrance colonnade with doric columns supporting a moulded entablature. At its centre is a raised parapet with the Royal coat of arms in relief at its centre. Whilst the Commonwealth Bank occupied the building the Customs service was moved back into the adjacent timber building. In 1969-70 extensions were made to the rear of the building and in the late 1980s conservation and restoration works were undertaken. In 2004 the Customs House was sold to the present owners and currently houses a financial planning firm. (information taken from: Queensland Heritage Register, retrieved on 17 May 2005 at <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600669&back=1>) Part of a panorama. See also negative numbers: 184652, 184655, 184656, 196826.

records.dc:title: Early morning view of Cunningham Street, Dalby, ca. 1935
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments architectural features main streets Dalby (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Photographs have been taken from an album donated by Allan Queale. The photographs focus on the town of Dalby which is located on the Darling Downs, approximately 220 kms west of Brisbane, on the Warrego Highway. Myall Creek, a tributary of the Condamine River, runs through the town. Although the area is known as Queensland's wheat centre, other forms of farming include a thriving cotton industry, which spreads from Dalby, south to Goondiwindi and west across to St George.

records.dc:title: Treasury Building, Brisbane, ca. 1896
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: official buildings buildings, structures & establishments facades (places) stone buildings towers architectural features Brisbane - Buildings - Treasury Building, ca. 1896 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Treasury Building, at the corner of George and Queen Streets, was erected in three stages between 1886 and 1928. In 1883 a design competition for a two-storeyed building was won by Melbourne architects Grainger and D'Ebro. However this design was never used as the Queensland Colonial Architect, John James Clark, argued that the site warranted a four-storeyed complex. Clark's own design, entered in the competition prior to his appointment, was used. When completed in September 1889, the new building was occupied by the Premier, Colonial secretary, Registrar-General, Treasury, Mines, Works, Police and Auditor-General. Stage two which completed the Elizabeth Street section was commenced almost immediately and was completed by February 1893. This new wing was occupied by the Registrar of Titles, Justice, Works, Public Instruction and the State Savings Bank. Work on the third state commenced in 1922 and officially opened in 1928, providing expanded accomodation for the existing tenants. The building is now home to an international casino and restaurants. (Information taken from: Queensland Heritage Register, retrieved on 7 December 2004 at <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600143&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Jowett 10 at Thornton Street, Surfers Paradise, 1953
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: motor vehicles timber houses fences Jowett (cars) Motor Vehicles 1930-1940 Jowett 10 automobile Surfers Paradise (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A Jowett 10 'Sports Tourer', probably 1937. The Jowett 10 was produced between 1936 and 1939, and was powered by an 1,166cc flat four engine. The mechanical parts of this Australian delivered car were imported from England, but the body is Australian designed and built. The side curtain windows would usually be detached to create very good ventilation for the passengers.

records.dc:title: Caves Boarding House at Stanthorpe, ca. 1917
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: Colonial architecture architectural features balconies verandas fences Stanthorpe - Boarding Houses, Caves Boarding House, ca. 1917 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:description: Portrait of Margaret Marr, nee Roberts, taken in Chester, Cheshire, 1853. She married Nathaniel Ebenston on 16 March 1872 at the Presbyterian Church, Leichhardt Street, Brisbane. Nathaniel died of Typhoid on 14 June 1879 at Spring Hill. Margaret later married John Fyfe Marr. She died of Dengue Fever on 30 March 1905. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Portrait of Doctor Thomas Lane Bancroft, ca.1895
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits Bancroft, Dr Tom Bancroft, T. L. (Thomas Lane), 1860-1933
records.dc:description: Portrait of Doctor Thomas Lane Bancroft taken from the family collection. He was well known as a medical naturalist. Thomas was born on the 2 January 1860 and came to Brisbane with his parents and sister in 1864. After graduating from Edinburgh University in 1883 he practised in Ann Street, Brisbane, from 1889 to 1894. Thomas Bancroft served as a quarantine officer for the port of Brisbane, government medical officer in 1908 and medical officer on Palm Island in 1930. He undertook many other investigations ranging from blood parasites of birds to Aboriginal food-plants and hybridization of cotton. Absorbed in natural history he made an indirect contribution to knowledge over a wider field on which he published eighty-four papers. He died on the 12 November, 1933 (Information taken from Australian dictionary of biography, v.7, 1992).

records.dc:title: Town procession in Barcaldine, Queensland, ca. 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: trucks processions streets festivals, celebrations etc. Barcaldine - Processions, ca. 1920 Barcaldine (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Decorated trucks and floats parade down the main street in Barcaldine. Barcaldine is a town in the central west of Queensland 108kms east of Longreach. It is situated on Lagoon Creek and is the centre of a pastoral area devoted to the production of sheep and some beef cattle. There is good supply of artesian water and the town's wide streets are lined with flowering shade trees. Barcaldine is known as the Garden City of the West. The town takes its name from Barcaldine Downs Station, which was named by Donald Charles Cameron, a pioneer pastoralist who had stayed with family in Barcaldine, Ayrshire before migrating to Australia. Barcaldine figured prominently in the 1891 shearers' strike, when 400 shearers camped on the fringes of the town for several months protesting the use of non-union labour. The strike gave birth to the political Labor movement. In the following year Thomas Ryan, a member of the state committee, became the first endorsed Labor candidate in the Australian parliament. The Australian Worker's Heritage Centre celebrates the contribution made by workers in pioneering and building Australia.(Information taken from 'The Australian Encyclopedia' v.1, 1965)

records.dc:title: Executive Building, Brisbane, ca. 1907
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: official buildings horsedrawn carriages parks statues Brisbane - Buildings - Executive Building, ca. 1907 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Executive Building was erected by the Queensland Government during the years 1901-05 overlooking what is now Queen's Park. During construction it was known as the New Lands & Survey Offices but towards its completion became known as the Executive Building. The second floor housed the Premier's offices, his Under Secretary, officials of the Public Service Board and the Cabinet Room. On the third floor a large room facing the whole length of George Street was allotted to the Trustees of the Qld. National Art Gallery for the collection of works of art. The building, which later became the Land Administration Building, was entirely faced with stone. Granite was used for the base, course and plinth, with freestone above. It was erected on the site of Brisbane's first electric telegraph office and the former convict settlement's parsonage, later the commissariat officers' quarters. The gardens established adjacent to the building were initially known as the Executive Gardens. On 23 June 1906 a bronze statue of Queen Victoria was unveiled by the Governor. (Infromation taken from: Janet Hogan, Living history of Brisbane, 1982)

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: parks botanical gardens creeks trees Brisbane - Parks and Gardens - Bowen Park, ca. 1889 Bowen Park (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: A man sits at the water's edge of a creek which ran through Bowen Park, around 1889. The creek does not appear on present-day maps. Bowen Park originally filled the block of land bordered by Bowen Bridge Road, Gregory Terrace, Brookes Street and O'Connell Terrace, at Bowen Hills, and was the site of Acclimatisation Society of Queensland gardens. The park reduced in size as the R.N.A. showgrounds expanded.

records.dc:title: Business premises of James Croker & Sons, Mackay, 1939
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: petrol pumps service stations motor vehicles showrooms Mackay - Firms - James Croker and Sons, 1939 Business enterprises--Queensland--Mackay Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: James Croker & Sons has been a prominent business in Mackay since 1889. This single story building has an awning which runs the full length of the property protecting the large shop windows from the sun. There is a wide forecourt with three petrol pumps ajacent to the street. The name of the firm is painted onto the side wall of the building. In the early days the firm concentrated on shipping, but in time, it entered into other fields including fuels and oils, and motor vehicles.

records.dc:title: Stanthorpe Shire Council building, ca. 1922
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber buildings Stanthorpe - Buildings - Stanthorpe Shire Council, ca. 1922 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Proposed site for Wunderlich tile display on the corner of Barry Parade and Wickham Street, Brisbane
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: trams cars commercial establishments Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: In 1886, Ernest Wunderlich arrived in Australia to commence work as an agent for European manufacturers of building products. The founding of Wunderlich officially dates from its incorporation as a limited company in 1893, although installation of imported metal building components had started as early as 1886. Wunderlich produced a range of building components including sheeting and roofing products, metal ceilings, shop fittings and ornamental embossed metal decorations. The 'Durabestos' line of asbestos-cement sheeting components were produced by Wunderlich during the 1930s through to the 1950s. (Information taken from: Manuscripts Queensland, 2005, retrieved 8 August 2005, from <http://www.manuscriptsqld.slq.qld.gov.au/)

records.dc:title: Running the Cutter monument at Mount Morgan
records.dc:creator: Eunson, Mervyn
records.dc:subject: monuments & memorials miners mining Mount Morgan - Monuments and Statues - Running the Cutter Monuments--Queensland--Mt. Morgan Mt. Morgan (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Local custom of the Mount Morgan miners in the early 1900s was 'Running the Cutter'. The cutter itself was a large billy-can, or oversized quart pot. At crib time, the pit boy was sent to fetch beer for the miners, who each drank his cut. This representation shows the boy running up the hill and is situated in the main street of Mount Morgan. The custom is re-enacted today in an annual event. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Warwick Town Hall and adjacent shops, ca. 1890
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: clock towers sandstone buildings porticos town halls chemist shops Warwick - Buildings - Town Hall, ca. 1890 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: In this photograph the clock has yet to be installed. The ceremony of laying the foundation stone of this building, the third Warwick Town Hall, was attended by the Premier of Queensland, Sir Samuel Griffith and Lady Griffith. The ceremony took place on 12 August 1887. The first Town Hall was a slab building which had originally been built as the Court House at the corner of Albert and Albion Streets in 1849. In 1873 the Council purchased the Masonic Hall, a brick building in Palmerin Street, as the second Town Hall. This site was later occupied by the Warwick Argus newspaper office and from 1919 by the Warwick Daily News. On one side of the Town Hall is the chemist shop of C.H. Ward.

records.dc:subject: mine buildings headframes chimneystacks Mount Isa - Views, ca. 1933 Mount Isa Mines Limited Mines and mining--Queensland--Mt. Isa Business enterprises--Queensland--Mount Isa
records.dc:description: Mount Isa Mines Limited, community of operations and referred to as Mineside. The gazetted town of Mount Isa is situated accross the Leichhardt River on the other side of the hill with the lead stack and Urquhart head frame. In the foreground the intersection of School Road, Oriel Crescent, Hill Road and Jarrah Street. Most of these buildings were built between 1928 and 1931, during a period of optimistic expansion brought about by the infusion of overseas finance into Mount Isa Mines, firstly by Russo-Asiatic and then by ASARCO. records.dc:title: Grandmother Martin's shop at Dutton Park, Brisbane, ca. 1900
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: corner shops shops timber buildings verandas children handcarts women's clothing & accessories Brisbane - Suburbs - Dutton Park, ca. 1900 Dutton Park (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Shop of Janet Martin (nee Gray) on the corner of Annerley Road and Tillot Street. (Description supplied with photograph) The suburb of Dutton Park was originally known as Bloggo, which became corrupted to Boggo and thus gave the name to Boggo Road (now known as Annerley Road). The area was eventually renamed Dutton Park after Charles Boydell Dutton who was the Queensland Minister for Lands from 1883 to 1887. Originally the district was not popular with settlers because of early plans for the construction of the South Brisbane Cemetery and gaol. However the area eventually found favour due to its proximity to the city and the development of public transport. The South Coast Railway was built through the district and a station was opened at Dutton Park in 1884. Land was initially bought for farming, however residential development soon followed after the introduction of the tramline in 1908. (Information taken from: Queensland Place Names Board: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities, and Brisbites Suburban Sites, retrieved on 13 September 2004 at <http://www.ourbrisbane.com/living/suburbs/dutton_park/history/>)

records.dc:title: Sawyer Family
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits men's clothing and accessories children's clothing women's clothing & accessories families Sawyer Family (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Members of the family of Jessie David Sawyer who was Alderman for the East Ward of Brisbane in 1899. The family from left to right: Cyril Henry (Bill) Sawyer born 13 August 1888 (seated) and then his mother Patience Jemima Sawyer (nee Smith) wife of Jessie Sawyer, she was born 1858 and died 25 May 1916 in Brisbane. Then standing at centre back is Sidney Charles Sawyer, son of J. D. Sawyer and his wife. He was born 19 July 1881 in Brisbane, married in 6 November 1907 and died 7 July 1964. Sidney Sawyer later became a jeweller and one of his works, a buckle and belt, was in the Victoria and Albert Museum. He worked for Flavelle, Roberts and Sankey for a time, around 1904, and had a shop in Elizabeth Street, Brisbane around 1916-17. The next family member seated is Jessie David Sawyer who was either born or baptised 9 April 1854, married 20 July 1880 and died 16 October 1919. He was buried at Dutton Park Cemetery. His father was a tabacconist and Jessie may also have been one. He owned land at South Brisbane. The two girls are Ida May who was the older, born 19 December 1885 and Ruby Jane born 15 May 1887. This picture was probably taken after 1889 as another son died in 1889. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Haig's residence in Warwick, ca. 1890
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: children's clothing brick buildings verandas picket fences shingles Warwick - Residences - Haig's residence, ca. 1890 Warwick (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This house of sand bricks on a sandstone foundation was built for Henry Haig in the early 1880s on one acre of land at the western end of Albert Street. The first Haig, John, came to the Darling Downs with the Leslie Brothers in the early 1840s. He became not only the district's first Registrar, but also the first photographer in Warwick, thus founding the long standing family tradtion in this line of business.(Description supplied with photograph.) Warwick was the first town on the Darling Downs, established in 1849 on the banks of the Condamine River. The rich grazing land around the area supports horse and cattle studs, fine wool and grain. In 1871 the railway from Ipswich came through. Warwick is situated 158km south west of Brisbane on the Cunningham Highway. (Information taken from: M. Barca, Explore Historic Australia, 2002)

records.dc:title: Soden family residence in Annerley, Brisbane, ca. 1895
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: suburbs timber houses verandas women's clothing & accessories corrugated iron roofs Brisbane- Suburbs- Annerley, ca. 1895 Ipswich Road (Annerley, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Large colonial home belonging to the Soden family situated in Ipswich Road, Annerley. (Between Aubigny Street and Beaudesert Road, Post Office Directory, 1896-97, p.162) The suburb was named after the township of Annerley in the County of Surrey by the Hon. Digby Denham, an early Queensland premier. It was originally known as Stephens Shire after Thomas Blacket Stephens. The Soden family were early settlers in the area and ran a bus service between Annerley and Brisbane.

records.dc:title: Christue Street, Copperfield, ca. 1876
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: streetscapes buildings, structures & establishments horses horsedrawn vehicles Copperfield (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Copperfield was once a booming mining town and produced Queensland's first copper mine. The mine was the first to be worked commercially outside South Australia and also the first rich mine in Queensland. In 1862, a 10 feet high wall of solid copper ore was discovered at Copperfield. Mining continued until the 1880's when the best quality ore was mined out.Copperfield is located 5km south of Clermont in the Belyando Shire, North Queensland.

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: firefighters dogs uniforms bicycles helmets firefighting equipment hoses Fire Brigades - New Farm New Farm (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The first meeting of the New Farm Volunteer Fire Brigade was held on 11 September, 1889, at James Campbell and Sons' sawmill. Campbell offered land for a fire station and, by early December that year, constructed a fire station for 50 in Moray Street. (Information taken from: K. D. Calthorpe and K. Capell, Brisbane on fire : a history of firefighting 1860-1925, 1997) Queensland Museum holds some relics of the New Farm Volunteer Fire Brigade.

records.dc:title: Kedron Lodge, Kalinga, ca. 1937
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: Gothic revival (architecture) architectural features bunya-bunyas Kalinga (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Judge Lutwyche was the first resident judge in Moreton Bay in 1859 and he lived at Kedron Lodge, 119 Nelson Street, Kalinga. Kedron Lodge is a large two-storeyed two-storeyed Gothic style dwelling built of locally quarried sandstone. The foundation stone for the building was laid in 1860. Christopher Potter and John Petrie built Kedron Lodge.

records.dc:title: Russian Orthodox Church of Saint Nicholas, Woolloongabba, Brisbane, ca. 1936
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches religious structures & establishments spires cupolas Brisbane - Churches - Woolloongabba - Russian Orthodox Church of Saint Nicholas, ca. 1920s Russian Orthodox Church of Saint Nicholas (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Russian Orthodox parish in Woolloongabba was established by white Russians fleeing the Russian revolution. Initially they worshipped in St Thomas' Anglican Church in South Brisbane. In 1925 they purchased a cottage in Vulture Street and converted it into a church. In 1935 the old church was moved to the back of the block so that a new church could be built. This was the first purpose built Russian Orthodox Church constructed in Australia. The new church was designed by Mr Gregory Mekhonoshin and given to a firm of Architects, Messrs. Cavanagh and Cavanagh, for final professional preparation. The new church was completed in 1936. (Information taken from: Galina Zakrjevsky, History of St Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral in Brisbane, Australia 1923-1993, 1997)

records.dc:title: Sketch of William Pettigrew, ca. 1888
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits sketches collars beards Pettigrew, William (Portraits)
records.dc:description: William Pettigrew (1825 - 1906) was a sawmiller, land speculator and owner from 1882 to 1887 of the site on which the Princess Theatre at Annerley Road, Wooloongabba was later erected. In 1887 Pettigrew sold the land to Philip Hardgrave, a prominent Brisbane solicitor, who occupied chambers in Queen Street and owned a private residence 'Wangothin' in Montague Road, West End. Hardgrave appears to have been responsible for building the South Brisbane Public Hall (later named the Princess Theatre) in 1888. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Brisbane in 1862
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: town views roads & streets buildings, structures & establishments rivers Brisbane - Views, 1862 St. Stephen's Church (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: This view of Brisbane in 1862 shows the area around the old Women's Factory Prison. The prison is the building behind the partly completed Normal School. Brisbane's present GPO building was erected near the site of the prison. On the right of the prison is St Stephen's Church, still standing. Edward Street can be seen running down the hill. Queen and Adelaide Streets can also be clearly seen.

records.dc:title: Second Wickham Terrace Presbyterian Church in Brisbane, 1890
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches bell towers steeples church architecture Brisbane - Churches - Wickham Terrace Presbyterian Church, 1890 Wickham Terrace Presbyterian Church (Brisbane, Qld.) Presbyterian church buildings--Queensland--Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This church, which replaced the first one on the corner of Creek Street, was opened for service on 6 November 1887. The Railway Department later resumed the property including the church, and in 1901 when Central Station came into use the building became a repository for Railway Department records. From 1929 to 1941 it was used as a gymnasium. In 1942 it was leased to the Congregational Church who remained until 1960. The building has now been demolished to make way for new roadworks in the area. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Edward Acre demonstrating the new splint which he invented, 1939
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: splints medical equipment first aid inventors inventions Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Caption on photo: Brisbane Man's Invention Wins Praise. 'The perfect splint; a surgical instrument rather than a first-aid appliance.' That is how a leading Brisbane doctor has described the invention of Mr. Edward Acres, an ambulance bearer of 14 years' experience, who is attached to the Q.A.T.B.'s Ann Street headquarters. The new Acres splint, the result of months of research and construction, it is expected, will revolutionise ambulance and hospital treatment of fractures. Already plans are under way to have it generally used in Queensland...The entire limb is open to constant supervision and the extension is of the extension-counter-extension type. It is firmly constructed of stainless steel with chrome fittings, and immediately impresses the technical man with its outstanding simplicity of operation.

records.dc:title: St. John's Cathedral, Brisbane, ca. 1915
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: cathedrals Gothic revival (architecture) church architecture churches Brisbane - Churches - St. John's Cathedral, c.a 1915 St. John's Cathedral (Brisbane, Qld.) Brisbane (Qld.)--Buildings, structures, etc Church buildings--Queensland--Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: St Johns Cathedral is believed to be the last Gothic Cathedral in the world to be completed. It was designed by architect John Pearson and has taken over 100 years to complete. The 13 metre tall final tower, weighing 22 tonnes, was lifted into place on the 11th of November 2008. The cathedral is believed to be the last Gothic Cathedral in the world to be completed. The Archbishop of Brisbane, Dr Phillip Aspinall, officially consecrated the completed Cathedral on Thursday 29th October 2009, 108 years after the laying of the foundation stone. The Cathedral dominates the smaller buildings in the foreground of the image. Pyrmont Private Hospital is in the foreground.

records.dc:subject: buildings, structures & establishments town halls palm trees clock towers lawnmowers Brisbane - Buildings - South Brisbane Town Hall, 1948 City halls--Queensland--Brisbane Buildings--Queensland--Brisbane
records.dc:description: A red brick building with an ornate clock tower and archway. South Brisbane Town Hall, in Vulture Street, was built in 1892 with an impressive tower with provision for four six foot diameter clock dials but it was not until 1904 that the council could afford the 100 for a clock. Since the dissolution of the City of South Brisbane in 1925, the building has had many different occupants but the clock , which may actually be the world's first electrically controlled tower clock, has continued to tick on in tribute to its maker.

records.dc:title: Honourable Anderson (Andrew) Dawson
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits politicians premiers ministers (government) Dawson, The Hon. Anderson (Andrew) (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Anderson (Andrew) Dawson was born on 16 July 1863 in Rockhampton. He was the son of Anderson, a miner, and Jean Dawson (nee Smith). He married Caroline Quinn in 1887. He was a Queensland politician from 1893 to 1901 and became Australia's first Labor Premier in 1899. He was a Federal Senator from 1901 to 1906 and Federal Minister for Defence from April to August, 1904. (Information supplied with photograph and taken from Queensland Parliament website, 2005, retrieved on 22 February 2005 from <http://www.parliament.qld.gov.au/Parlib/Parl_Information/Historical/membregisterHB.pdf>)
