records.dc:subject: bridges official events crowds panoramic views cars houses Stanthorpe - Bridges - Carnarvon Bridge, 1922 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Looking down Sandgate Road to the Tram Terminus, Clayfield, 1921
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: roads & streets residential streets houses fences tramways power & telegraph poles Brisbane - Suburbs - Clayfield, 1921 Sandgate Road (Clayfield, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Caption on photo: From Adelaide Street to the terminus, Clayfield. Clayfield was presumably named because of its former importance in the brickmaking industry. There were several clay pits in the area in the late 1800s. The name 'Clayfield' first appears in the Post Office records in 1891 as a section in the Hamilton and Toombul Streets Directory. However the area was settled well before this, some time between 1853 and 1858. The area was popular because of its proximity to the city and sought after elevated breezes. In 1855 the pastoralist, James Sutherland, became the owner of a substantial amount of land in the Toombul Parish, including land in Clayfield. The tramway was opened to Clayfield in 1899 and soon after shops began to appear at its terminus. This tram service was discontinued in 1969 and replaced by buses. Clayfield today is one of the prestige suburbs of Brisbane boasting many fine houses and gardens, combined with tree-lined streets. (Information taken from: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities: Information from the Queensland Place Names Board, and Brisbites Suburban Sites, retrieved on 22 June 2004 at <http://www.brisbites.com/suburbView.asp>)

records.dc:description: The first contingent of the US forces to arrive in Australia arrived at Hamilton Wharf in Brisbane on 22 December 1941. The convoy named Task Force South Pacific included the escort ship USS Pensacola and USS Chaumont, USS Republic and USS Meigs; they had been diverted from the Philippines. The convoy disembarked a total of 4600 personnel. (Information taken from: http://www.naa.gov.au/about-us/publications/fact-sheets/fs234.aspx)

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: schoolchildren schools & colleges timber buildings children's clothing picket fences Stanthorpe - Schools & Colleges - Stanthorpe State School, ca. 1905 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Workers of The City and Suburban Parcel Delivery Bryce Ltd., Brisbane, ca. 1916
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: carriers delivery carts people associated with transport work clothes groups (people) Brisbane - Firms - City and Suburb Parcel Delivery Bryce Ltd., ca. 1916 City and Suburb Parcel Delivery Bryce Ltd. (Brisbane, Qld.) Parcel post--Queensland--Brisbane
records.dc:description: The City and Suburban Parcel Delivery Bryce Ltd' began operations some time in 1887 from 134-136 Adelaide Street. In 1888 it was re-registered as 'Bryce and Battersby'. In 1889 it was re-registered as 'Thomas Bryce and Co.' On 29 September 1900 it was re-registered back to its original name when Thomas's brother John Menzies Bryce joined the business. Other partners were Thomas's wife Janet Bryce, Charles Woodhead & Alfred Faulkner. In 1950 it was re-registered as 'Bryce Limited' until it's demise under the directorship of Thomas Bryce Jnr.

records.dc:title: Central Railway Station Brisbane, Queensland, 1901
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: railway stations architectural styles roads & streets Brisbane - Railway Stations - Central Railway Station, 1901 Central Railway Station (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Central Railway Station and clock tower in Ann Street, Brisbane. The double storey sandstone construction has moulded arches over the windows and doors with gable decorations on the roof. 'The above represents the elevation of the Brisbane Central Railway Station, according to the approved design upon which the tender has been accepted. Built in ca.1901 the building has standstone facings from Helidon, pink stone from Pearson's quarry and white stone from Pippard's quarry. The building was taken over by the department on the 26 July,1901 at a cost of forty nine thousand two hundred and seventy seven pounds fifteen shillings and eleven pence'. [Information taken from: Evening Observer, 13 May, 1889; and, Votes and proceedings, v. 4, 1909]

records.dc:creator: Unidentified

records.dc:title: Grand Hotel Bundaberg, 1907
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns verandas balconies ironwork architectural features Bundaberg - Hotels - Grand Hotel, 1907 Pub architecture--Queensland--Bundaberg Grand Hotel (Bundaberg, Qld.) Bundaberg (Qld.)--Buildings, structures, etc. Bundaberg (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Grand Hotel opened June 1885. It is located on the corner of Bourbong and Targo Streets, Bundaberg. (Description supplied with photograph.) The builing occupies the corner of the main street and Targo streets. Featuring two floors with decorative iron lacework on brackets between vertical supports, with a balustrade on the second floor also made of intricate iron lacework. The roofline appears to be flat with finials. There is an inset on the lower right hand corner of the interior of the hotel.

records.dc:subject: schoolchildren schools & colleges children's clothing timber buildings men's clothing and accessories Stanthorpe - Schools & Colleges - Thorndale State School, ca. 1900 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Customs House, Bundaberg, ca. 1910
records.dc:creator: Avenell, F. W.
records.dc:subject: customs houses official buildings buildings, structures & establishments brick buildings picket fences Bundaberg - Buildings - Customs House, ca. 1910 Customs House (Bundaberg, Qld.) Buildings--Queensland--Bundaberg
records.dc:description: The custom house, surrounded by a wooden fence, is situated on the corner of Quay and Barolin Street. Opening in 1902, the building is of red brick and plaster construction - made by Fischer's Bricks in Bundaberg from a clay quarry and brick works once in production on the site of Salter Oval. The lower portion is utilised for all matters connected with customs, excise, and shipping transactions, whilst the upper floor provides fine dwelling quarters for the Sub-collector of customs. Later, ca. 1920, converted to use as Commonwealth Bank. (Information taken from: Eadie's Illustrated Bundaberg Almanac, 1911, p. 8)

records.dc:title: Washing the tin in the mines at Stanthorpe, 1872
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: tin mines miners mining rocks mining objects wheelbarrows men's clothing and accessories Stanthorpe - Mines, 1872 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:title: Chinchilla families outside the Soldiers' Memorial Hall, 1925
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber buildings children's clothing women's clothing & accessories mens' clothing and accessories monuments & memorials touring cars hats Chinchilla - Buildings - Soldier's Memorial Hall, 1925 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The hall is a large wooden building with an entrance porch on the eastern side of Heeney Street. Families, wearing formal clothes and hats, are gathered outside. Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Information taken from: Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Bardon in the 1930s
records.dc:creator: Bloomer, James Vincent
records.dc:subject: views suburbs Brisbane - Suburbs - Bardon, 1936 Bardon (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The photograph was taken from Lugg Street, Bardon, looking towards the Gap. The suburb of Bardon was named after Bardon House, built by Joshua Jeays, an architect and a partner of Andrew Petrie in the construction of the Petrie Terrace Goal. Bardon House was named after Jeays' birthplace, Bardon Hill in Leicestershire, England. Joshua Jeays was an alderman of the first Municipality of Brisbane from 1859 to 1864, when he became the Mayor. The area that is now Bardon was first surveyed on 12 November, 1862. This was followed by the sale of the land, with only three buyers showing interest: Joshua Jeays, Francis Lyon and Edward Wyndham Tufnell. Tufnell became the first Anglican Bishop of Brisbane. Another person of influence to live in Bardon was Sir Charles Lilley, the editor of the Moreton Bay Courier and Premier of Queensland from 1868 to 1870. Sir Charles played an important role in the introduction of the Education Act of 1875, which provided free education to all. Landmarks of Bardon include a 70 feet high water tower built in 1927 to supply water to the higher parts of Brisbane, and 'Fernberg' house, now the Government House. The house was built in 1865 by J. C. Heussler and purchased by the government in 1910. Another famous feature of Bardon is Ithaca Creek, named after the birthplace in Greece of Lady Bowen, wife of the first governor of Queensland. (Information taken from: Queensland Place Names Board, Brisbane suburbs and localities; ourbrisbane.com : your city online, retrieved 7 June 2004, from <http://www.ourbrisbane.com/living/suburbs/bardon/history/>)

records.dc:subject: private school students teachers schools & colleges school uniforms groups (people) Brisbane - Schools and Colleges - Brisbane Grammar School, 1897 Brisbane Grammar School Portraits, Group--Queensland--Brisbane School buildings--Queensland--Brisbane
records.dc:description: Brisbane Grammar School is a non-selective independent day and boarding school for boys located on a wonderfully landscaped and heritage listed site in the centre of Brisbane. The School opened in 1868 on its Roma Street site and soon after relocated to its present site on Spring Hill over-looking the central business district of Brisbane. It now caters for about 1400 boys in Years 6 to 12, with boarders from Year 7.

records.dc:title: Opening of the Memorial Hall, Chinchilla, Queensland, 1925
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber buildings touring cars monuments & memorials community centres Chinchilla - Buildings - Soldiers' Memorial Hall, 1925 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Touring cars outside the Memorial Hall in Chinchilla in 1925. Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Information from Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade at Ipswich, 1908
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: ambulances horses buildings, structures & establishments horsedrawn vehicles buggies wagons Ambulances - Ipswich, ca. 1908 Ipswich Hospital Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade. Brisbane Centre Ipswich (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This view shows the Ipswich subcentre of the Brisbane Brigade at Downs Street, North Ipswich. Workers pose with an ambulance wagon, litter and sulky. The litter was pulled to the patient by a sulky, usually pulled by a white horse. The litter was then pushed to the hospital by hand. A lantern would hang from the litter at night. On nearing the hospital, a bearer would blow a whistle and a wardsman would open the gates (Information taken from: R. Patrick, Ipswich Hospital 1860-1991, 1993).

records.dc:title: Group of women sitting on the front steps at Ardmore homestead Stanthorpe, ca. 1920s
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber houses verandas groups (people) women's clothing & accessories balustrades Stanthorpe - Residences - Ardmore, ca. 1920s Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: House and grounds (6 acres) was given to the Uniting Church in 1987 by W. B. Fleming and daughter. The house was originally the summer residence of Nellie and James Forsyth. and later of their niece Ivy Philp, who gave it to the Flemings. There was a small orchard in the grounds of the homestead. (Description supplied with photograph) Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Port Office in Edward Street, Brisbane, 1889
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: official buildings verandas buildings, structures & establishments Brisbane - Buildings - Port Office, 1889 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description:
The Port Office was built in 1879-80 to a design by the Colonial Architect, F. D. G. Stanley. The contractor was John Petrie. In 1885 a two-storey extension was constructed at the rear of the building. In 1929 the building was extended to provide more space for the Department of Labour which had occupied the building since 1906. In 1988 the property was leased to a private company and the building became part of the Heritage Hotel complex. Extensive renovations were undertaken, including the removal of all post 1880 additions, and the addition of the end balconies which were shown on the Colonial Architect's original plans. (Information taken from: Queensland Heritage Register, retrieved on 14 December 2004 at )

NSW Photographic Co., Petrie Terrace.

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: schools & colleges playgrounds students verandas picket fences Ipswich - Schools and Colleges - Ipswich National School, ca. 1890 Ipswich National School School buildings--Queensland--Ipswich
records.dc:description: The first official schools were called National Schools. In Ipswich, the first National School was opened in atemporary building 'down a laneway leading off Nicholas Street to the railway goods yards'. The teacher was John Scott. A new school building opened in 1862 on land bounded by Limestone, Gordon and Brisbane Streets. Theschool had several different locations and had separate sections for girls and boys, not always housedtogether. It eventually evolved into Central State School, now located in Griffiths Road.

records.dc:title: Enclosure in King George Square for scrap aluminium, Brisbane, January 1942
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: enclosures buildings, structures & establishments garden beds street scenes motor vehicles advertising signs men's clothing and accessories women's clothing & accessories military uniforms World War II - Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Collections of aluminium articles were to assist the war effort. Children in Brisbane suburubs made collections and articles could be left at department stores and suburban post office depots. The employees of the company which provided the City Council's garbage service also collected aluminium articles. All aluminium articles collected were taken to the Milton Depot where they were collected by the Army authorities. (Description taken from: Courier Mail, 16 January 1942, p. 8. See also Courier Mail 14 January 1942 p. 5)

records.dc:description: Edward Castell Osborn (born Daventry, England and died Brisbane, Queensland) was the late Archdeacon of Toowoomba and Wide Bay and Residentary Canon of St. John's Cathedral, Brisbane. records.dc:title: Two sketches of the Brisbane residence, Dara, ca. 1890
records.dc:creator: Bihan, E
records.dc:subject: drawings houses brick houses building construction religious structures & establishments Brisbane - Residences - Dara Brisbane (Qld.) Dwellings--Queensland--Brisbane
records.dc:description: Before becoming the residence of Archbishop Quinn, old 'Dara' had (until 1859) been the residence of William Augustine Duncan (the Sub-Collector of Customs at Moreton Bay) for whom Dara was built in 1850. Archbishop Quinn lived there from his arrival in 1861, and his successor, Archbishop Dunne, lived there until travelling to Rome in 1890. It was during Dunne's absence that the old residence was demolished and replaced by the new one, which was ready for his return in 1891. It appears that the residence was on the site of the proposed Holy Name Cathedral, which is near Duncan Street, Fortitude Valley, where Duncan's name is perpetuated. The Archbishop's residence, Dara, was demolished and a new residence built on the site. The illustrations are for the magnificent new Dara on the top and the original house below.

records.dc:title: A.10 locomotive on display for the Railway Pageant at Ipswich, 1936
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: locomotives steam engines steam trains railway carriages railways railway lines Railways - Locomotives (steam), 1860-1870 Steam locomotives--Queensland Ipswich (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This A.10 locomotive was built by Neilson & Co., Glasgow in 1866, then shipped to Rockhampton, arriving on 21 August. It was numbered 3 of the Great Northern (later Central) Railway. In 1882 it was shipped to Brisbane, becoming 2nd no. 3 of the Southern and Western Railway. In 1901 it was sent north to shunt Bowen Wharf. It was returned to Brisbane in 1913, where it was exhibited in Albert Square for the Queensland Government Railways 50th Anniversary of turning the first sod. It was then stored at Ipswich until 1936, when it ran under its own steam at the Railway Pageant. It was then preserved under cover at the Roma Street Railway Yards complex until it was removed to Ipswich Workshops in 1959. It is now displayed in Queens Park, Ipswich. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Wilson family members on the lawn at Claremont, Milford Street, Ipswich, 1912
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses gardens architectural features families men's clothing and accessories women's clothing & accessories Ipswich - Residences - Claremont, 1912 Ipswich (Qld.)
records.dc:description: From left: Mary Wilson, her future husband Bernard Smithers, Harriet Wilson (wife of the owner of Claremont John Wilson), Ivor Wilson, Cecil Wilson, John Wilson (owner) and Enid Wilson (later wife of Rev. Christopher Compton), standing at back, Gordon and Harriet Wilson, reclining) and Charles Morris. Mrs O'Connor, motron of Ipswich Girl's Grammar School and Ellis Skyring, Police Magistrate, are seated on the portico. Claremont was purchased by John Cecil Norman Wilson ca. 1903. He was a son of George Harrison Wilson, the founder of G. H. Wilson and Company, Ipswich. (See Fox, M, History of Queensland, v.1, pt. 2, p. 467). J. C. N. Wilson worked in the family business and died in 1922. On his death Claremont reverted back to the Wilson estate and cousin Sumner Wilson lived there until ca. 1935. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Railway yards at Chinchilla, ca.1909
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: railway yards goods wagons hotels and taverns timber buildings Chinchilla - Streets - Chinchilla Street, ca;1909 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Shunting yards and wagons on the lines outside the Chinchilla Station opposite the Commercial Hotel around 1909. Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Information taken from: Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Thomas Finney of Finney, Isles & Co.
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits moustaches businesspeople politicians men's clothing and accessories Finney, Thomas (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Thomas Finney, born Ireland 1837, immigrated to Queensland on the Flying Cloud. Established Finney, Isles & Co., retail and wholesale merchants in Queen Street. Finney acquired the Princess Theatre at Woolloongabba in 1899. During his ownership the premises were used as a clothing factory but by 1910 the downstairs portion of the Princess was also in use as a venue for the screening of silent motion pictures. Thomas was MLA for Toowong from Mar 1896-November 1900. (Information taken from A Biographical Register of the Queensland Parliament 1860-1929, p. 56)

records.dc:creator: Sandercoe, Carolyn
records.dc:subject: cars Antique and classic cars--Queensland--Brisbane Jowett automobile Kenmore (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This car was made in Bradford, West Yorkshire. It was firstr registered in Brisbane in December 1949 and was purchased by the second owner, Cecil Sandercock in January 1952. The car was then inherited by his son, Kenneth Sandercoe in February 1956. The car was de-registered in 1966 and restoration commenced in 2005. It was re-registered in February 2006. The car is outside Carolyn Sandercoe's home at 15 Currong Street in Kenmore. The driver is Ken Sandercoe and is accompanied by his wife Valerie. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Reverend Thomas Mowbray and his wife Williamina Mowbray
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits pioneers ministers of religion Mowbray, Rev. Thomas (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Thomas Mowbray was born in Hamilton, Scotland in 1812, arrived in Australia 1841 and moved to the Moreton Bay Settlement in 1847. He came to be called the 'Father of Presbyterianism in Queensland', opening Brisbane's first Presbyterian Church for public worship in May 1851 in Grey Street, South Brisbane. In the late 1840s Reverend Mowbray purchased eleven acres of riverfront land, now the site of Mowbray Park, East Brisbane. He built his big stone house 'Riversdale' on a grassy knoll with views of the river. Thomas Mowbray established a school at 'Riversdale'. At the time of his death his estate was eighty-three acres stretching from the present Lytton Road through to Logan Road. (Information taken from: Old Mowbraytown, 1988)

records.dc:title: William Deagon of Sandgate
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits mayors sketches Deagon, William (Portraits)
records.dc:description: William Deagon was a Sandgate identity and his name, Deagon, was used for the locality when the railway line went through in 1887. He owned the Sandgate Hotel, a stopping place for the Cobb & Co. coaches. He was the mayor of Sandgate in 1882, 1883 and 1884. Deagon Street, the racecourse, the railway station and the Deagon Wetlands now bear his name. (Information taken from BRISbites website, 2005, retrieved on 21 February 2005 from <http://www.brisbites.com/suburbView.asp?suburb=157&topic=5>)

records.dc:title: Front view of the Military Hospital at Stanthorpe
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: military hospitals Colonial architecture architectural features radio masts tents Stanthorpe - Hospitals - Military Hospital Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Commercial Hotel in Chinchilla ablaze on 25 August, 1922
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: fires fire-damaged buildings hotels & taverns Chinchilla - Fires, 1922 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Commercial Hotel in Chinchilla Street was destroyed by fire in the early morning. Mrs O'Sullivan was the owner and occupier of the hotel. (Information from: Courier Mail, 29 August, 1922) Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Information taken from: Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Cyclone damage to a theatre at Mackay , 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage buildings, structures & establishments theatres accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a consequent tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts a man posing in the remains of a theatre largely demolished by the cyclone.

records.dc:title: Brisbane River, between New Farm and Hawthorne, during the 1931 flood
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: floods rivers Brisbane - Floods, 1931 (Hawthorne) Brisbane River (Qld.) New Farm (Brisbane, Qld.) Hawthorne (Brisbane, Qld.) Hawthorne (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: People gathered at the water's edge at Hawthorne with a view across to CSR refinery at New Farm, during the 1931 Brisbane floods. People have come on foot carrying umbrellas, or on bicycles to view the damage caused by the floodwaters. A number of children have waded out into the water. It was probably at the site of the Blondells Engineering on Scott Street. Today, the Hawthorn location is next to the Hawthorn Ferry terminal and Hardcastle Park. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Estate map of Logan Estate at Brookfield, Brisbane, 1922
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: maps plans land sales land auctions Brisbane - Suburbs - Brookfield, 1922 Brookfield (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: This real estate map (no. 910) shows Upper Brookfield and Pullenvale. (Description supplied with photograph) Auctioneers: Barnes & Co. Ltd., Roma St., Brisbane. Surveyors: R.A. Hamilton & James, 171 Queen Street. Brookfield, regarded as one of Brisbane's later developing suburbs, actually was one of the earliest areas settled. The fertile country in the district was farmed as early as 1850 with dairying and small crops being the main occupation. By the early 1870s population growth warranted the establishment of the first primary school in the area. Timber getting was also an early industry and there are the remains of a number of old gold mines in the district. Brookfield remained a quiet farming community until recent years when it became one of Brisbane's 'Green Belt' suburbs with larger housing blocks preserving the pleasant bush setting. Brookfield was named by either Mrs L. Logan, an early resident, because of the abundance of meadows, creeks and gullies, or by Mrs Lucinda Brimblecombe in 1868 at a residents' meeting to give the district a name. Mrs Brimblecombe is reported to have suggested that since the area had so many flowing brooks the district should be called Brookfield. (Information taken from: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities: Information from the Queensland Place Names Board)

records.dc:title: General store of Lindenberg & Company, Pittsworth, ca. 1910
records.dc:creator: Pardey, J. H.
records.dc:subject: shops advertising signs corrugated iron roofs unsealed roads Pittsworth (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Pittsworth is a small rural community near Toowoomba, on the Darlinig Downs. It is a service centre for the surrounding farms which grow cereal crops, cotton, linseed and sunflowers. There are also beef cattle properties in the area. Lindenberg & Co. was founded by Charles Lindenberg in 1889. It was taken over by his son Henry Lindenberg in 1910. Henry controlled the business until it was taken over by his sons in 1958. This building was in Yandilla Street. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: School children outside the Chinchilla Shire Council Chambers in 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: childrens clothing flags local goverment official buildings timber buildings verandas corrugated iron roofs Chinchilla - Buildings - Chinchilla Shire Council Chambers, 1918 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Shire Chairman, G.G. Woods addressing school children in front of the Shire Offices in Bell Street, Chinchilla. The Council Chambers were built in 1915 and were used until 1948 (Description supplied with photograph) Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Information taken from: Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Young girl outside a house in Clarence Road, Indooroopilly, Brisbane, ca. 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber houses unsealed roads children paling fences verandas eucalypts children's clothing corrugated iron roofs Brisbane - Suburbs - Indooroopilly, ca. 1920 Clarence Road (Indooroopilly, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Near the corner of Prince Street. (Description supplied with photograph) Indooroopilly is a leafy riverside suburb in Brisbane's west and derives its name from either the Aboriginal term for running water or gully of leeches. The suburb was first settled in 1860 when Mr H C Rawnsley purchased land south of Witton Creek and in 1861 built the first house in the area, named Witton Manor, on the site of the present Nudgee Junior College. Development was slow until 1875 when a rail service was provided from Brisbane, after which houses and firms soon sprang up. In 1876 the first railway bridge was built. This was swept away in the disastrous 1893 flood, but was rebuilt. The Walter Taylor Bridge (commonly known as the Indooroopilly Toll Bridge) was built in 1936 and linked Indooroopilly to Chelmer. (Information taken from: Queensland Place Names Board: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities)

records.dc:title: Loretto, formerly Aubigny, ca. 1917
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses hospitals architectural features verandas women's clothing & accessories Brisbane - Residences - Aubigny, ca. 1917 North Quay (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Aubigny, was erected on North Quay near the interesction with Makerston Street. Built by Mr Samuel Davis it was bought by Mr Patrick Perkins who named the house Aubigny, after the Darling Downs electorate that had sent him to the Legislative Assembly. It included a small brick Synagogue in the grounds, close to the two-storey main building. The Sisters of Mercy took possession in late 1905, after Patrick Perkins death, and prepared the builiding for use as the first Mater Misericordiae Hospital which opened in January 1906. The Synagogue was turned into a chapel, later owners used it as a billard room. The Mater Hospital, had 20 beds, at a charge per patient of three guineas a week. In September, 1910, patients were transferred to the new Mater Private Hospital on College Hill (now Mater Hill), South Brisbane. After the closure of the North Quay house, its name was changed to, Loretto, and it became a hostel for Catholic girls from the country who came to work in Brisbane. It was demolished ca. 1939 to make way for the Church of Christ Scientist. (See also image number 18914)

records.dc:title: Anderson's General Store, Stanthorpe, ca. 1899
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: men's clothing and accessories women's clothing & accessories buildings, structures and establishments timber buildings general stores produce stores trolleys cages Stanthorpe - Firms - J. Anderson, ca. 1899 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Produce and general store is a timber building built on a corner. Goods are displayed on the footpath under the verandah and include bags of produce. The shop has a wrap around verandah and display windows each side of the front doors. Mr and Mrs Anderson are pictured standing outside their store. Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Daniel Currie of Nambour, ca. 1890
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits suits (clothing) Currie, Daniel (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Born in Jacksonville, Illinois, USA, in 1837. Came to Queensland in 1859, from Victoria. With his brother John erected Nambour's first general store ca. 1890/1891. Prior to that was a farmer at Petrie's Creek. He and his brother were amongst the original shareholders in the Moreton Cental Sugar Mill. Currie Street in Nambour is named after him. He died in Brisbane on 31 March 1910, after a long illness. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Perkins family pictured outside their home, Stanthorpe, ca. 1874
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits families children's clothing women's clothing & accessories men's clothing and accessories Perkins family (Portraits) Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Perkins family lived at 115 Granite Street, Stanthorpe. Lewis Linnet Perkins was born in Northhampton, England, on 1st February 1835 and died after an unfortunate accident in Stanthorpe on 3rd October 1874. He was Stanthorpe's first fatal accident. Lewis and Ann Palmer were married on 23rd October 1854. The Perkins family arrived in Australia in 1856 , came to Queensland in 1861 and settled at Stanthorpe in 1874. The family is pictured from left: George Lewis Perkins, Frederick William Perkins, Charles Alfred Perkins, Lewis Linnet Perkins, Lizzie Perkins (born at Croydon, England, on 18th October 1855), Francis Edwin (Frank) Perkins, Mrs Lewis Perkins (nee Anne Palmer), Emma Perkins (born 22 January 1858, later Mrs Robertson) and Walter Perkins. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Ipswich Girls' Grammar School, ca. 1935
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: Girls' schools private schools schools & colleges Ipswich - Schools & colleges - Ipswich Girls' Grammar School, ca. 1935 Ipswich Girls' Grammar School--Buildings School buildings--Queensland--Ipswich Historic buildings--Queensland--Ipswich Ipswich (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Ipswich Girl's Grammar School is approached from the highest point of Brisbane Street near the Chermside Road fiveways intersection. ...The Administration building was the first building constructed on the site. It is a classical two storey rendered brick building, designed by Brockwell Gill, that was constructed in stages from 1892. The first stage consisted of the central portion with a transverse gabled wing to the left hand end. Another transverse gabled wing was added at the right hand end in 1901, completing the symmetry of the building. The gabled ends have pilasters rising up through two storeys and terminating in three semi-circular arches above the upper storey windows. The date of construction of each wing is inscribed in raised lettering below each central upper window. The central portion of the facade consists of a ground floor arcaded verandah with a central semi-circular arch leading to the central entrance door. This semi-circular arch is repeated on the upper verandah and is surmounted by a central gabled roof. Timber finials and decorative timber fretwork are at the end of each gable. (Information taken from: CHIMS (Department of Environment and Resource Management), 2009, retrieved 29 June, 2010, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/chims/placeDetail.html?siteId=1534>)

records.dc:title: Opening of the Enoggera Tramway, August 1949
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: trams groups (people) openings (events) commercial establishments streetlights Brisbane - Suburbs - Enoggera, ca. 1949 Enoggera (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Huge crowds welcomed the first tram to Enoggera in August 1949 when the one and a quarter mile extension from Alderley was opened. The Lord Mayor, Alderman Chandler, drove through the ribbon at the Samford Road and Wardell Street terminus located west of the intersection. The first tram was a newly designed 'pride of the fleet' fully enclosed with a capacity for more than 110 passengers. The trams ceased operation on the 13th April, 1969. (Information taken from: Barbara Gunn, Enoggera district heritage trail, 2001)

records.dc:title: Parliamentarian John McMaster, Brisbane, ca. 1895
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits politicians mayors shopkeepers McMaster, John (Portraits) Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Born on the island of Islay, Scotland, in 1830. Died in Brisbane on 29 February 1942. In 1854 he came to Queensland as a farmer. Around 1870 he became a storekeeper at Fortitude Valley, in Brisbane, and was elected an Alderman of that ward two years later. He subsequently represented Fortitude Valley in the Municipal Council for many years. He was elected Mayor of Brisbane for the first time in February 1884 and re-elected in 1890, 1893 and 1897. During the financial crisis of 1893 he proved his ability when the municipality found itself without funds to continue urgent works. McMaster raised 225,000 pounds with debentures. He was elected to the Legislative Assembly in September 1885. He supported the construction of the railway from Roma Street through the city and to Fortitude Valley. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Pierpoint & Sons shop staff pictured at Stanthorpe, 1949
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: groups (people) personnel ladie's clothing & accessories men's clothing and accessories Stanthorpe - Firms - Pierpoint & Sons Ltd., 1949 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Back row from left: Robert O'Brien, Robert Bathesby, Robert Leake, Vic Ross, Ray McLady, Ivan Smith, Roy Werner. Middle Row from left: Stan Thorpe, Lance Morrison, Jack Pierpoint, Percy Howe, Jack Rick, Dick Hilton, Don Kent, T. J. Fraser. Front from left: Jacqualine Pierpoint, Beryl Gleeson, Miss Butler, Cynthia Brooks, Marie Muir, Noela Boatfield, Dorothy Cooper, Mrs. Stan Winton, Nellie Reid, Patricia Pierpoint. (Description supplied with photograph) Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

This photograph was taken during his occupation. It was then bought by the Presbyterian and Methodist Schools to found Blackheath, the girls' boarding school, opening in 1921. The structure was destroyed in a fire in 1992.

records.dc:description: Erected in George Street on the site of the early Brisbane Hospital, this magnificent building was commenced in 1876 and officially opened on 6 March 1879. An arsonist set fire to the building on 1 September 1968, and much of the structure was destroyed. The surviving parts of the building were demolished in October 1976, prior to the construction of the new law courts complex. records.dc:title: Church of England in Chinchilla, 1941
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: traction engines churches timber buildings labourers building removal Chinchilla - Churches - Church of England, 1941 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Relocation of the Church of England from the corner of Helena and Middle Streets to Colamba Street. The move was done by Emmerson Brothers using a traction engine.(Description supplied with photograph) Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Information taken from Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Cyclone damage to Croker's Wharf at Mackay , 1918
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: storm damage wharves ships trees buildings, structures & establishments accidents & disasters cyclones Mackay - Cyclones, 1918 Mackay (Qld.)
records.dc:description: A disastrous cyclone hit the coast of Queensland in January 1918, one of the hardest hit areas being Mackay, which was inundated by a consequent tidal wave on the 20th and 21st of that month. For some period after the eye passed through Mackay the outside world had no real idea of the devastation, as all communications had been cut: telegraph lines were down and dangerous seas prevented any navigation to the port of Mackay. The cyclone and the accompanying deluge (about 266mm were registered) wreaked havoc in the town of Mackay and particularly on the waterfront. Buildings were partially destroyed, unroofed, and overturned; Croker's stores on the riverfront were flattened. The ship 'Tay' although in reasonable condition, and the barge 'Apa' were aground on the north bank, and the Sydney Street Bridge no longer spanned the river (Information taken from: please view TimeWalks http://www.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/timewalks/mackay_1926/5088_132577.htm ). This image depicts Croker's Wharf and the Leichhardt Tree at Mackay after the storm. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Store belonging to Joe McLucas at Stanthorpe, ca. 1898
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: shops window displays men's clothing and accessories women's clothing & accessories advertising signs unsealed roads kerbing & guttering Stanthorpe - Firms - J. McLucas, ca. 1898 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Charming shop which appears to be a confectionery store and tea rooms. Cadbury chocolate signs are positioned above the window on the left. Both shop windows have delicate displays with lace backdrops. Two elegantly dressed ladies standing in front of the shop are wearing black, one of them being Miss Shelford. Mr Joe McLucas is third from left. Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15th ed.)

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: suburbs Colonial architecture architectural features verandas picket fences Brisbane - Suburbs - Toowong, ca. 1900 Historic houses--Queensland--Brisbane Toowong, Qld. Belle Vue
records.dc:description: Colonial residence of Mr J. Badger. The timber home has an iron roof and wrap-around verandahs with decorative iron balustrades. Mr Badger, originally from the United States, was managing director of the Brisbane Tramway Company from 1897 to 1922.

records.dc:title: Advertisement for Cope & Newman, Coachbuilders, Dutton Park, Brisbane, 1889
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: advertisements coachbuilders horsedrawn coaches carriage factories Brisbane - Suburbs - Dutton Park, 1889 Dutton Park (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Corner of Annerley Road and West Street. (Description supplied with photograph) The advertisement includes a diagram of the premises and drawings of various coach designs. The suburb of Dutton Park was originally known as Bloggo, which became corrupted to Boggo and thus gave the name to Boggo Road (now known as Annerley Road). The area was eventually renamed Dutton Park after Charles Boydell Dutton who was the Queensland Minister for Lands from 1883 to 1887. Originally the district was not popular with settlers because of early plans for the construction of the South Brisbane Cemetery and gaol. However the area eventually found favour due to its proximity to the city and the development of public transport. The South Coast Railway was built through the district and a station was opened at Dutton Park in 1884. Land was initially bought for farming, however residential development soon followed after the introduction of the tramline in 1908. (Information taken from: Queensland Place Names Board: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities, and Brisbites Suburban Sites, retrieved on 13 September 2004 at <http://www.ourbrisbane.com/living/suburbs/dutton_park/history/>)

records.dc:title: Bardic chair presented to the winning bard at the Royal National Eisteddfod of Wales, 1937
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: chairs Welsh in Queensland Chairs
records.dc:description: Article accompanying photograph reads: Bardic Chair for 1937. Queenslands gift to Wales. The bardic chair to be presented to the winning bard at the Royal National Eisteddfod of Wales this year will be a gift from Queensland. It is of Queensland design, workmanship, and materials, except for the tapestry seat which was specially made in England, but which is typically Queensland in motif, bearing a representation of two koalas. The most striking part of the chair is its back panel of satin ash, carved in bas relief and polychromed with Welsh scenery and traditional Welsh figures. At the top are Snowden and Harlech Castles, and lower down on the panel are scenes of Welsh life, with a meeting of the gorsedd, the opening of the Eisteddford, in the bottom left-hand corner, and a Welsh ministrel with harp and boy in the bottom right-hand corner. The chair is surmounted by the Queensland coat of arms, surrounded by a wreath. This wreath and the torch on the stretcher bars underneath the seat are symbols of victory. At the top of each column is a Tudor crown, in recognition of the fact that Wales supplied England with its first Tudor king, Henry VII. The front legs are of cup and cover design, and the back legs are carved in late Gothic style. The principal wood used is bronzed maple. The chair, which has been constructed to last for centuries, was designed and manufactured by Mr Edward Rosenstangel in his Brunswick Street factory. The Royal National Eisteddfod of Wales will be held this year at Machynlleth, and the time will be, as usual, the first week in August. Mr E. A. Rawson, president of the Association of Welsh Societies of Australia, will leave for Britain on the Orama on March 17, and will personally present the chair to the Esiteddfod authorities. It will be the second bardic chair from Queensland, the first having been sent from Ipswich in 1927. Accompanying letter from the National Library of Wales dated 2 December 1982 reads: Our annual National Eisteddfod was held in 1937 in Machynlleth, Montgomeryshire . The chair was donated by the Brisbane St. Davids Society and was won for an ode on Y Ffin (The Border) by T. Rowland Hughes (1903-1949) who later became a successful novelist.

records.dc:title: Lydia Goodliff Sandercock and son Edwin
records.dc:creator: Cecil Edwin Sandercock
records.dc:subject: portraits hats beaches families women's clothing & accessories children's clothing Sandercock Family (Portraits) Woody Point (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Lydia Goodliff Sandercock (nee Filsell) and son Kenneth Edwin Sandercoe (ne Sandercock) aged two and a half years, taken in the summer 1923-24 by Cecil Edwin Percival Sandercock at the Moreton Bay side of Woody Point, using an Ensign, quarter inch plate, F.8 folding camera. In the background is the bathing sheds, most of which belonged to private houses, but there were two large ones for public use. In those days, one walked to the beach in street clothes and cahnged into bathing costume in the bathing sheds. The last one disappeared around WWII. Lydia and Cecil purchased a house on the corner of Kate and Annie Streeets in 1923, and sold it in 1948. It was sold and rmoved to Clontarf a few years later. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Casual gathering of foundation pupils and teachers of St. Catherine's School, Stanthorpe, 1911
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: groups (people) schools & colleges schoolchildren nuns children's clothing women's clothing & accessories Stanthorpe - Schools & Colleges - St. Catherine's School, 1911 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Pupils and teachers are gathered around a group of granite rocks. One little boy is holding his teddy and another has a ball. Several of the girls are holding dolls. There is a nun dressed in her habit in the centre of the group. Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Kedron Lodge, a Kalinga residence, ca. 1914
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: stone houses gardens architectural features Gothic revival (architecture) Brisbane - Residences - Kedron Lodge, ca. 1914 Kalinga (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Exterior view of Kedron Lodge, 119 Nelson Street, Kalinga. The building is an example of a Colonial Gothic house built in sandstone in the early 1880s by Christopher Potter and John Petrie for Judge Alfred James Lutwyche (1810-1880), Queensland's first Supreme Court judge. Kedron Lodge is a large two-storeyed dwelling beside Kedron Brook. Built of sandstone its irregular silhouette is created by several steeply pitched gable roofs and five brick chimneys. (Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency, 2007, retrieved 30 March 2007, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600238&back=1>)

records.dc:description: Samuel Allen established a produce store in Flinders Street, Townsville in 1872. He was the first businessman to introduce steam power for chaff cutting and corn crushing. records.dc:title: View of Queens Hotel through the palm and fig trees of the Strand and Anzac Park, Townsville, 1938
records.dc:creator: North Queensland Register
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns palm trees fig trees parks Townsville - Hotels - Queens Hotel, 1938 Queens Hotel (Townsville, Qld.) Hotels--Queensland--Townsville
records.dc:description: Erected in several stages between 1902 and 1928, was once considered the finest hotel in North Queensland. In 1899 the property and license were purchased by John Henry Tyack. He called for designs to replace a timber building with a substantial brick structure. The winning entry was submitted by architects Eaton, Bates & Polin, who had opened an office in Townsville c.1901. Arthur Polin was managing partner of the Townsville office. The 1920s additions and alterations were designed by Townsville architect Walter Hunt. The final stage along Wickham Street was erected in 1926-28. (Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency, 2006, retrieved 27 April 2009, from www.epa.qld.gov.au )

records.dc:title: Patient in his room at the Stanthorpe Sanatorium, ca. 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hospitals patients Tuberculosis sanatoriums hospital beds pipes (smoking) men's clothing and accessories Stanthorpe - Hospitals - The Sanatorium Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Patient is lying on his bed reading a book and smoking his pipe. The Tuberculosis sanatorium was established at Kyoomba, Stanthorpe circa. 1918. Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Queens Park, Brisbane, ca. 1938
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: parks garden beds Brisbane - Parks and Gardens - Queens Park, ca. 1938 lawns
records.dc:description: View across Queen's Park. Palm trees, trimmed lawns, and flower beds set the scene for a relaxing moment in the park. The old Executive Building stands on the left with a statue of Queen Victoria, first unveiled by Lord Chelmsford in 1906, in front of it. Field guns were located in the park either side of the Queen Victoria memorial, commemorating Queensland's participation in the South African War of 1899-1902. Motor cars can be seen parked along George Street.

records.dc:title: Reverend Thomas Mowbray
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: portraits ministers of religion pioneers Mowbray, Rev. Thomas (Portraits)
records.dc:description: Thomas Mowbray was born in Hamilton, Scotland in 1812, arrived in Australia 1841 and moved to the Moreton Bay Settlement in 1847. He came to be called the 'Father of Presbyterianism in Queensland', opening Brisbane's first Presbyterian Church for public worship in May 1851 in Grey Street, South Brisbane. In the late 1840s Reverend Mowbray purchased eleven acres of riverfront land, now the site of Mowbray Park, East Brisbane. He built his big stone house 'Riversdale' on a grassy knoll with views of the river. Thomas Mowbray established a school at 'Riversdale'. At the time of his death his estate was eighty-three acres stretching from the present Lytton Road through to Logan Road. (Information taken from: Old Mowbraytown, 1988)

records.dc:title: Side view of Milton House with the Manning family on the verandah, 1868
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: houses architectural features shingle roofs verandas families Brisbane - Residences - Milton House, 1868 Milton (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Milton House was erected in 1852 or 1853 for retired Queen Street chemist Ambrose Eldridge.This hip-roofed house is Colonial Georgian in style and plan, having a typical front doorway with segmented sidelights with arched fanlight, and a symmetrical arrangement of rooms radiating off a central hallway on each floor. The ground floor has wide, open verandahs on three sides. Two service rooms run across the rear of the house incorporating pavilion wings off the side verandahs. The walls are of brick, which is lime rendered and jointed to give the impression of stone. A three-roomed cellar is constructed of rough rubble walling, and entered by steps on the south side of the verandah. The roof is covered in shingles. Milton House was originally built as a homestead, high on the riverbank overlooking the surrounding property and survives sufficiently in form, feature and material, to be important in demonstrating the principal features of Colonial Georgian architecture adapted to local climatic conditions, notably through the inclusion of verandahs and french doors on three sides. (Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency, 2007, retreived 3 April 2007, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600253&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Band Sunday at Botanical Gardens, Brisbane, ca. 1911
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: botanical gardens palm trees crowds hats Brisbane - Parks and gardens - Botanic Gardens, ca. 1911 Parks--Queensland--Brisbane
records.dc:description: The City Botanic Gardens are the citys oldest park, originally planted by convicts in 1825 with food crops to feed the prison colony. These gardens include ancient trees, rainforest glades and exotic species. They run the full length of Alice Street, bordered by Parliament House on the one side and the Brisbane Rivers northern banks on the other. At the rear of the gardens is Brisbane River Stage, in which many council concerts and big band names take place.

records.dc:title: Border Baker, Stanthorpe, 1872
records.dc:creator: Boag, William
records.dc:subject: slab huts buildings, structures & establishments bakeries groups (people) Men's clothing and accessories Stanthorpe - Firms - Border Bakery, 1872 Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This was one of seven bakeries in early Stanthorpe. Bread was a staple of the miner's diet and the wheaten loaf or damper, made when brewer's yeast could not be procured, went well with black tea, salted meat and potatoes. Ground maize, boiled rice and other things were added to the bread which was later stamped with its maker's initials. A two pound loaf sold in Stanthorpe for about 6 pence in 1873. (Description supplied with photograph) Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Brighton Family Boarding House at Cleveland, 1871
records.dc:creator: Boag, William, 1838?-1878
records.dc:subject: private hotels horse-drawn carriages side-saddle riding Cleveland - Boarding Houses - Brighton Family Boarding House, 1871 Cleveland (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The early part of William Boag's career was spent in Sydney where he was in partnership with portrait photographer Joseph Charles Milligan. (Images made by Boag are in the collection of the Campbelltown and Airds Historical Society.) Boag arrived in Queensland in November 1871. He travelled around the south-east, along the foreshore of Moreton Bay and the township of Cleveland. He then moved into the Logan and Albert area where he captured images of local crushing mills and sugar plantations. While at Yatala, he took on a partner, John Henry Mills, and by the end of 1872, both men were in Stanthorpe where they remained for several months, producing views of the booming tin-mining settlement. In July 1873, after stopping off in Warwick, Boag and Mills extended their operations to Mackay, where they remained until October 1875. During this time, Boag made trips to St Lawrence and Cooktown, however his movements after this are difficult to trace. It is known that by mid 1876 he was at Copperfield and Clermont, and in February 1878, he inserted a notice in the Peak Downs Telegram announcing that he was leaving for the west. Then information ceases abruptly. It is possible that Boag never reached his destination, since his death certificate records that he died in 1878 at an unknown location. The Brighton Boarding House in Shore Street was constructed around 1851 by pastoralist Francis Bigge (of Mt Pleasant station). It was intended originally to be a dwelling house, but finding it too near the road, Bigge rented it out. After many changes, it became the Brighton Hotel, then, in the 1950s, it was renamed the Grand View hotel. At the time that this photograph was taken, Cleveland's principal attractions were a good supply of salt air and fresh seafood, or as one satirical observer reported, 'people come down here to eat oysters and fresh fish...and (to) wash and be clean'. Accomodation included two public houses, and board and lodging was to be had in 'almost every second humpy'. One eyesore was the Cleveland racecourse, located on the Government Reserve, which for a long time had been the favourite resort of pigs that were allowed to 'grub up' the turf in search of wild yams and other delicacies, leaving large holes which made the ground unsightly and dangerous.

records.dc:title: Street procession with the Pipe and Drums of Chinchilla, ca. 1920
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: pipers kilts Highland dress cars horsedrawn vehicles Chinchilla - Procession, 1920 Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Decorated horsedrawn vehicles follow the pipe band as it passes the Grand Hotel on the corner of Heeney and Bell Streets. The piper is dressed in traditional Highland costume. The Grand Hotel was later burnt down. Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Brisbane's first School of Arts building on the corner of Queen and Creek Streets, ca. 1872
records.dc:creator: Boag, William, 1838?-1878
records.dc:subject: freemasons masonic halls interiors (buildings) furniture Brisbane - Buildings - School of Arts, ca. 1872 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The School of Arts building is arranged for a Masonic ceremony in the early 1870s. This venue was used temporarily by the North Australian Lodge, when a new meeting place had to be found in 1872. The brethren left the Old Masonic Hall and later moved to the Town Hall, which became their new quarters. The North Australian Lodge was the first established in the Colony and derived its name from the hotel in Queen Street where its earliest meetings had taken place. John Petrie, Sir Charles Lilley and Ratcliffe Pring were foundation members of this distinguished group of freemasons. *Please note that this image is inverted. The early part of William Boag's career was spent in Sydney where he was in partnership with portrait photographer Joseph Charles Milligan. (Images made by Boag are in the collection of the Campbelltown and Airds Historical Society.) Boag arrived in Queensland in November 1871. He then moved into the Logan and Albert area where he captured images of local crushing mills and sugar plantations. In July 1873, after stopping off in Warwick, Boag and Mills extended their operations to Mackay, where they remained until October 1875. During this time, Boag made trips to St Lawrence and Cooktown, however his movements after this are difficult to trace. It is known that by mid 1876 he was at Copperfield and Clermont, and in February 1878, he inserted a notice in the Peak Downs Telegram announcing that he was leaving for the west. Then information ceases abruptly. It is possible that Boag never reached his destination, since his death certificate records that he died in 1878 at an unknown location.

The Honorary Secretary was Jas. C. Dexter. (Description supplied with photograph) Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.)

records.dc:title: Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade, Bundaberg Centre, ca. 1907
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: ambulance stations ambulance officers buildings, structures & establishments official buildings Bundaberg - Buildings - Q.A.T.B., ca. 1907 Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade. Bundaberg Centre Ambulance service--Queensland--Bundaberg Bundaberg (Qld.)--Buildings, structures, etc.
records.dc:description: An auxiliary service to the hospital, it's equipment consisted of a hard iron-tyred litter with stretcher. During the next year, a horse-drawn vehicle brought patients in more quickly. In 1912, a two-story brick ambulance building was erected in Maryborough St. (Information taken from: Janette Nolan, Bundaberg : history and people, 1978, p.191). The Queensland Transport Brigade opened in this building at the lower end of Boubong street on 30 August 1907. This image shows two ambulance officers, Mr Thygesen and friend, with bags ready, standing under the awning of the wooden building, with the iron-tyred litter outside.

records.dc:title: People's Palace after extensions were added, Ann Street, Brisbane, ca. 1913
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: private hotels buildings, structures & establishments architectural features Brisbane - Hotels - People's Palace Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The People's Palace was built on the corner of Ann and Edward Streets by the Salvation Army in 1910-1911. It was a temperance hotel built near the Central Railway Station in Brisbane. The rules were strictly no alcohol or gambling. It existed to provide affordable accommodation for working class people. In 1913 two more storeys were added to the original three storey building. (Information taken from: The Department of Environment and Heritage registers and inventory website, 2006, retrieved 13 February 2007 from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index>)

records.dc:title: Chinchilla Church of England, Queensland, 1941
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches timber buildings traction engines labourers building removal Chinchilla - Churches - Church of England Chinchilla (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The photograph shows the relocating of the Church of England from its original site of Helena and Middle Streets to Colamba Street. The move was done by Emmerson Brothers using a traction engine. (Description supplied with photograph) Chinchilla is a thriving town in the western Darling Downs, 295km NW of Brisbane on the Warrego Highway. Ludwig Leichhardt named the area in 1844 after jinchilla, the local Aboriginal name for cypress pines. Grain-growing is the traditional industry, as well as cattle, sheep, pigs, timber and more recently, grapes, cotton and watermelon. The cactoblastis insect was introduced to eradicate the prickly pear cactus infestation and the Cactoblastis Memorial Hall has been erected at Boonarga 8km east of Chinchilla. (Explore Australia 2003, Penguin Books Australia Ltd., 2002)

records.dc:title: Menzies Boarding House on the north face of Edward Street, Brisbane, ca. 1872
records.dc:creator: Boag, William, 1838?-1878
records.dc:subject: private hotels streetlights verandas balustrades main streets kerbing & guttering Brisbane - Boarding Houses - Menzies Boarding House, ca. 1872 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The early part of William Boag's career was spent in Sydney where he was in partnership with portrait photographer Joseph Charles Milligan. (Images made by Boag are in the collection of the Campbelltown and Airds Historical Society.) Boag arrived in Queensland in November 1871. He travelled around the south-east, along the foreshore of Moreton Bay and the township of Cleveland. He then moved into the Logan and Albert area where he captured images of local crushing mills and sugar plantations. While at Yatala, he took on a partner, John Henry Mills, and by the end of 1872, both men were in Stanthorpe where they remained for several months, producing views of the booming tin-mining settlement. In July 1873, after stopping off in Warwick, Boag and Mills extended their operations to Mackay, where they remained until October 1875. During this time, Boag made trips to St Lawrence and Cooktown, however his movements after this are difficult to trace. It is known that by mid 1876 he was at Copperfield and Clermont, and in February 1878, he inserted a notice in the Peak Downs Telegram announcing that he was leaving for the west. Then information ceases abruptly. It is possible that Boag never reached his destination, since his death certificate records that he died in 1878 at an unknown location. This boarding house was owned by John Menzies, a former licensed victualler, and was situated between Margaret and Mary streets. It probably had just been erected when William Boag arrived back in town from Cleveland to photograph Brisbane's houses, shops and public buildings.

records.dc:title: Sunday school class in the old Cleveland Court House, ca. 1871
records.dc:creator: Boag, William, 1838?-1878
records.dc:subject: Sunday schools courthouses police stations students shingle roofs Cleveland - Buildings - Court House, ca. 1871 Buildings--Queensland--Cleveland Cleveland (Qld.)
records.dc:description: For six years, before the opening of St Paul's Sunday School, local children assembled for Sunday instruction in this cottage, which was erected in 1854 for his timber workers by Francis Bigge, a Cleveland identity and sawmill proprietor. records.dc:title: Two storey Biloela Hotel, at Biloela, ca.1940
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: hotels & taverns cars verandas blinds Biloela (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The double storey hotel has a top verandah with cane blinds and a lower verandah extending into the street. Several cars are parked in front of the hotel. Biloela is in the fertile Callide Valley, 142 km south-west of Rockhampton. The name of the town comes from an aboriginal word for 'white cockatoo'. The Gangulu tribe inhabited the area before European settlement. Ludwig Leichhardt explored the region in 1844. Today, water from artesian bores irrigates crops of lucerne and cotton. The area is rich in coal with the Callide power stations producing about 20 per cent of Queensland's electricity. Beef production is also a major industry and the Biloela meat works are the third largest in Queensland. (Information taken from: Banana Shire Council database, 2002-2004, retrieved 25 August 2004, from http://www.banana.qld.gov.au/index.php/3 , Walkabout database http://www.walkabout.com.au/locations/QLDBiloela.shtml and Explore Australia, 2003.)

records.dc:title: St John's Cathedral and the Deanery taken from a north-easterly aspect in about 1928
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: cathedrals parsonages Gothic revival (architecture) Brisbane - Churches - St John's Cathedral (Anglican), ca. 1928 St. John's Cathedral (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The cathedral was designed by the English architect J L Pearson, however the start of construction was supervised by Robin Smith Dods. The first stage of the building process was finished in 1910, and in 2004 the final stages are now being completed. The cathedral was originally to be placed on the Queen's Park site ( where the Pro Cathedral stood) but later changed to the current site in Ann Street, Brisbane. The Deanery was erected in 1853 by John Petrie for Dr William Hobbs, and later altered as Governor Bowen's temporary residence. The Church of England later purchased the building and it became the Deanery.

records.dc:title: Bundaberg Rowing Shed, ca. 1928
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: rowing clubs (places) buildings, structures & establishments Bundaberg - Buildings - Rowing Shed, c.1928 Bundaberg Rowing Club Rowing--Queensland--Bundaberg Bundaberg--Buildings, structures, etc.
records.dc:description: Bundaberg Rowing Club's boathouse and entertainment pavillion, situated at the end of Quay Street, on the banks of the Burnett River and Saltwater Creek. Erected at a cost of about 1,400 pounds, exclusive of furnishings. The bottom portion is fitted up to house the club's boats and dressing and bath rooms. The top portion, which is 84 feet by 36 feet, contains cloak rooms and kitchenette, and has besides balconies 132 feet by 12 feet on river and creek frontages, a dance floor 72 feet by 36 feet. (Information taken from: The Burnett & Isis Pictorial, c. 1927)

records.dc:title: Aerial view of Clayfield, Brisbane, ca. 1920s
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: suburbs aerial views houses roads & streets racecourses Brisbane - Suburbs - Clayfield, ca. 1920s Clayfield (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Adelaide Street, East, is in the centre of the image. Eagle Farm Racecourse is visible in the top right. Clayfield was presumably named because of its former importance in the brickmaking industry. There were several clay pits in the area in the late 1800s. The name 'Clayfield' first appears in the Post Office records in 1891 as a section in the Hamilton and Toombul Streets Directory. However the area was settled well before this, some time between 1853 and 1858. The area was popular because of its proximity to the city and sought after elevated breezes. In 1855 the pastoralist, James Sutherland, became the owner of a substantial amount of land in the Toombul Parish, including land in Clayfield. Clayfield today is one of the prestige suburbs of Brisbane boasting many fine houses and gardens, combined with tree-lined streets. (Information taken from: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities: Information from the Queensland Place Names Board, and Brisbites Suburban Sites, retrieved on 22 June 2004 at <http://www.brisbites.com/suburbView.asp>)
