records.dc:title: Chairs designed and built by Ed. Rosenstengel, Brisbane, 1946
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture making upholstery chairs fabrics Wilson, Leslie Orme, Sir Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Sir Leslie Orme Wilson, former Governor of Queensland, who acted as Chairman of the Red Cross Appeal Committee during the war period, and Lady Wilson, former President of the Division, photographed at Government House. The Wilsons are pictured just prior to their departure overseas, with their Rosenstengel chairs. The chairs were presented to them by Red Cross workers throughout Queensland. Lady Wilson is sitting in one of the chairs which is a replica of the one beside which Sir Leslie Orme Wilson is standing. (Description supplied with photograph) The chairs are made from Queensland maple and covered in pin weave fabric by A.H. Lee of Birkenhead, England. Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958.

records.dc:title: Methodist Church at Stanthorpe
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: churches timber buildings picket fences architectural features Stanthorpe - Churches - Methodist Church Stanthorpe (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Stanthorpe is the commercial centre of the Granite Belt in Queensland. The region is unique for its wide seasonal variations, occasionally snowing in winter. The name Stanthorpe comes from the Latin word 'stannum', meaning tin, and the English word 'thorp' meaning village. The town grew around a coaching station established in 1857 and boomed in 1872 when tin was discovered near Quart Pot Creek. Fruit growing and winemaking are the two main industries in Stanthorpe today. (Information taken from: UBD Queensland Country Link Street & Travel Directory - 15 ed.) The Methodist Church was erected in 1877 and closed in 1914 but was still used as a Sunday School until 1924.

records.dc:title: Napier tourer on its record breaking Brisbane - Toowoomba run, 1912
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: motor vehicles caps men's clothing and accessories fences Napier (cars) Motor Vehicles 1910 - 1920 Napier automobile
records.dc:description: 6 cylinder, British built, Napier Tourer 1911 or 1912 model.(Description from KES & RGD) Caption from photograph reads: 'On 1 October 1912, Mr Walter M. Trevethan of 418-420 Adelaide Street, Brisbane, made a motor car record from Brisbane to Toowoomba, his time being 3 hours 7 minutes. He had a puncture on the road, and lost 10 minutes and was blocked at the Railway Gates at Redbank and lost 6 minutes. The record has never been lowered although attempts have been made. Included in Mr. Trevethan's party were 3 passengers, Mr Will Stevens, Mr H. M. Russell and Mr Frank Hooper. Mr Trevethan is satisfied that he can do the journey in 2 hours 30 minutes if necessary'. The Garage contains approximately 500 images of vehicles used in Queensland Australia, covering the period from 1900 . The images are linked to an index of the State Library of Queensland's extensive collection of automotive repair manuals.

records.dc:title: Sitting room in the Corones Hotel, Charleville, ca. 1930
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: living rooms furnishings hotels & taverns architectural features Charleville - Hotels - Corones Hotel, ca. 1930 Charleville (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Corones Hotel was built for Harry Corones on the site of the old Norman Hotel. It has a frontage of 210 feet on Wills Street and takes up almost the whole space between Edward and Galatea Streets. It took five years from the time the foundations were laid until completion in 1929. It cost in the vicinity of 50,000 pounds. The hotel had some of the best fittings and features of any hotel of the time, with en-suite bathrooms, embossed ceilings, wood paneling and stained glass windows. It also featured a jazz hall. (Description supplied with photograph)

records.dc:title: Castlemaine Brewery at Milton, Brisbane, 1879
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: breweries buildings, structures & establishments drawings brewery workers horsedrawn vehicles Brisbane - Breweries - Castlemaine Brewery, 1879 Castlemaine Perkins Limited Milton (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Castlemaine or Milton Brewery was established at Milton, Brisbane, in 1878 by Fitzgerald Quinlan & Co. The brothers Nicholas and Edward Fitzgerald had established brewing interests at Castlemaine in Victoria, and then in Adelaide, Perth, Sydney and Newcastle. In Brisbane, Quinlan Gray & Co. had taken over the interests of the Milton Distillery that was established on the site at Milton in 1870. The first brew by the new Milton Brewery was called Castlemaine XXX Sparkling Ale and was made to the same formula as the beer brewed by Castlemaine Brewery in Victoria. (Information taken from: Public Affairs Department, Castlemaine Perkins Limited, comp., History of the Castlemaine Perkins Brewery, 1877 - 1993, 1993). This drawing of the brewery depicts some laden wagons in the street in front of the three-storey building. A worker stands alongside. The signage reads: Castlemaine Brewery, Fitzgerald, Quinlan & Co.

records.dc:title: Ed Rosenstengel standing on the stairs of the Rosen and Cline workshop in Vancouver, British Colombia, ca. 1910
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture making furniture factories
records.dc:description: Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958.

records.dc:title: Carriers outside the firm Wright, Heaton & Company Limited, Charters Towers, 1905
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: carriers Charters Towers - Firms - Wright, Heaton & Co. Ltd., 1905 Wright, Heaton & Company Limited Business enterprises--Queensland--Charters Towers Carriers--Queensland--Charters Towers Charters Towers (Qld.)
records.dc:description: In January 1865 Francis Augustus Wright (1835-1903) began a carrying business with Edward Barber, styled Wright, Barber & Co. In 1875, when Edward Heaton (d.1894) joined them, the firm became Wright Heaton Barber & Co., general carriers and forwarding and commission agents. In February 1880 Wright Heaton & Co. Ltd was incorporated with Wright as chairman and managing director. In the 1880s Wright Heaton & Co., which had begun in Sydney, expanded into Queensland. (Information taken from: Australian Dictionary of Biography, Online Edition, 2006, retrieved 5 August 2010, from <http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A060473b.htm>)

records.dc:title: Jowett Eight commercial chassis with diesel engine, 1937
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: motor vehicles signs advertisments Jowett (cars) Motor Vehicles 1930 - 1940 Jowett automobile South Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: This Jowett is probably the smallest diesel powered vehicle ever sold in Australia for use on the road. The Jowett Eight commercial chassis was normally fitted with a 946cc flat twin petrol engine, but this example is fitted with the optional 1 litre flat twin Coventry Victor diesel engine for real smell-of-an-oily-rag fuel economy. Victor diesel engines were also used for powering electric generator sets in rural Queensland. The attached advertising board shows the vehicle was sold by Reo Motors of Grey Street, South Brisbane, distributors of the then-popular American Reo truck, and indicates the exceptional economy of operation buyers could expect. A van or utility body to meet the customer's requirements would be fitted by a local company.

records.dc:title: Normal School, Brisbane, ca. 1885
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: children schoolchildren schools buildings, structures & establishments fences Brisbane - Schools and Colleges - Normal School, ca. 1885 Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: View from the street of the Normal School, Brisbane. The Normal School was established as the National School in April 1860, and was conducted as a co-educational school until the opening of a boys' building in December 1862. The school building was designed by Christopher Porter and built by Andrew Petrie. Christopher Porter arrived in Brisbane in 1860, and was invited by the Queensland Board of Education to tender for the position as the Board's first general architect.

records.dc:title: Furniture for H.R.H. The Duke of Gloucester built by Ed. Rosenstengel, Fortitude Valley, Brisbane, 1934
records.dc:creator: Morden, Wilfred
records.dc:subject: furniture making chairs beds dressing tables stools upholstery Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: The royal bedroom for H.R.H. The Duke of Gloucester. A charming composition in the period, Louis XV, designed and built by Ed Rosenstengel. From an original watercolour drawing by Wilfred Morden. (Description supplied with photograph) The furniture includes carved wooden pieces: a wardrobe, bed, mirrored dressing table and stool, occasional chairs and a highboy. Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958.

records.dc:title: North Australian Lodge, Brisbane, ca. 1873
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: interiors (buildings) clubs, associations, societies etc. banners architectural feautres Brisbane - Clubs and Societies - North Australian Lodge, ca. 1873 Clubs--Queensland--Brisbane Brisbane (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Brisbane's first School of Arts building on the corner of Queen and Creek Streets, arranged for a Masonic ceremony in the early 1870s. This venue was probably used temporarily by the North Australian Lodge, when a new meeting place had to be found in 1872. The brethren left the Old Masonic Hall and later moved to the Town Hall, which became their new quarters. The North Australian Lodge was the first established in the colony and derived its name from the hotel in Queen Street where its earliest meetings took place. John Petrie, Sir Charles Lilley and Ratcliffe Pring were original members of this distinguished group of freemasons. (Description supplied with photograph.)

records.dc:title: Aerial view of Ascot, Brisbane, ca. 1925
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: aerial views suburbs houses roads & streets Brisbane - Suburbs - Ascot, ca. 1925 Ascot (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Windermere Road is on the left and Kitchener Road is at the top of the photograph, then Sutherland Avenue and Charlton Street. Beatrice Terrace is on the right, running parallel to Windermere Road. (Description supplied with photograph) The Brisbane suburb of Ascot was named after the famous racecourse in Berkshire, England. In the early 1830s convicts began clearing the land and building primitive roads. Ten years later wealthy free settlers took up land in areas where they could enjoy views of the Brisbane River. Ascot is now an affluent suburb featuring many imposing residences. The first racetrack in the area was opened in 1863, consisting of 332 acres of roughly cleared bushland and the area became a popular residential one for those concerned with the racing industry. Even as late as the 1920s there were racing stables throughout the suburb. Eagle Farm Racecourse, as it is now known, is the premier racecourse in Brisbane. The railway came to Ascot, then known as Hendra siding in 1882. (Information taken from: Brisbane Suburbs and Localities: Information from the Queensland Place Names Board)

records.dc:title: Interior of the Rosenstengel home at 72 Harcourt St, New Farm, Brisbane, ca. 1935
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: furniture making upholstery dining tables vases doors New Farm (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Edmund Rosenstengel (1887-1962) was born in Toowoomba. He learnt his trade as a cabinet-maker apprenticed to the business of Rosenstengel & Kleimeyer. He was later to work in Sydney, Auckland, Vancouver and Grand Rapids (USA), as well as in England and Europe, before returning to Toowoomba in 1911. In 1922 he came to Brisbane and commenced business on his own account in Fortitude Valley, where he was to remain until his retirement in 1958. His work was distinguished by the use of Queensland timbers, particularly Queensland maple and silky oak, together with elaborate carving and marquetry inlay. His best known public commissions include the invitation to furnish a bedroom at Government House, Brisbane, for the visit of the Duke of Gloucester in 1934, and a jewel case intended for the (then) Duchess of York. (Information taken from: K. Fahy and A. Simpson, Australian furniture: Pictorial history and dictionary 1788-1938, 1998.) Rosenstengel operated out of premises located at 524 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, from 1922 to 1958. This image shows two rooms separated by sliding glass panelled doors at the Rosenstengel home at New Farm. The furniture in these rooms is elaborately carved and includes tables, cabinets, and velvet upholstered occasional chairs.

records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: brick houses gardens shutters architectural features Brisbane - Residences - Baroona, 1886 Paddington (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: Baroona's front entrance with an unidentified man (possibly William D. Box) lying on the grass. The original residence of Baroona on Howard Street, Paddington, was designed by Benjamin Backhouse and built in 1866 for the Honorable William Draper Box, MLC. Baroona is a single storey brick building with a corrugated iron gabled roof and verandahs on all sides with shutters covering the casement windows.(Information taken from: Environmental Protection Agency database, 2007, retrieved 5 April 2007, from <http://www.epa.qld.gov.au/projects/heritage/index.cgi?place=600289&back=1>)

records.dc:title: Greycliffe Homestead in Biloela, Queensland
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: slab hut timber houses corrugated iron roofs verandas Biloela - Residences - Greycliffe Homestead, 1983 Biloela (Qld.)
records.dc:description: Greycliffe Homestead is a well-preserved slab hut construction built in about 1870. (Description supplied with photograph.) The home has been relocated into Biloela on the corner of Gladstone Road and Lawrence Street from its original position on Greycliffe Station. The Nott family lived on the property for over 100 years. Biloela is in the fertile Callide Valley, 142 km south-west of Rockhampton. The name of the town comes from an aboriginal word for 'white cockatoo'. The Gangulu tribe inhabited the area before European settlement. Ludwig Leichhardt explored the region in 1844. Today, water from artesian bores irrigates crops of lucerne and cotton. The area is rich in coal with the Callide power stations producing about 20 per cent of Queensland's electricity. Beef production is also a major industry and the Biloela meat works are the third largest in Queensland. (Information taken from: Banana Shire Council database, 2002-2004, retrieved 25 August 2004, from http://www.banana.qld.gov.au/index.php/3 , Walkabout database http://www.walkabout.com.au/locations/QLDBiloela.shtml and Explore Australia, 2003.) Photo taken by John Oxley staff on a field trip.

records.dc:title: Shorncliffe residence, Saltwood, ca. 1940
records.dc:creator: Unidentified
records.dc:subject: timber buildings private hotels cane blinds fences porticos Brisbane - Suburbs - Shorncliffe Shorncliffe (Brisbane, Qld.)
records.dc:description: The Shorncliffe residence 'Saltwood', was built in the 1870s. The home firstly belonged to G.L. Hart and was then bought by E. R. Drury. Saltwood was on the corner of Swan Street and Shorncliffe Parade and because of its proximity to Moora Park and the beach, was popular as a guest house. (Information taken from: Sandgate & District Historical Society and Museum, A Walk Around Sandgate, Vol.1, 1991)
